CRS_DESC: Galaxies and clusters of galaxies: their content, structure, dynamics, distribution, and motions; the cosmic microwave background: theory and observation; elements of observational cosmology. Prerequisite: PHYS-153L or PHYS-163L.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Selected topics in cosmology. Course content includes dark matter, dark energy, gravitational lensing, the cosmic microwave background, inflation, galaxy and galaxy cluster surveys. Prerequisite: ASTR 540.

An examination of the physical and biological laws that influence agriculture, pollution, population dynamics (including humans), climate, biodiversity and ecosystem structure and function. Not available for major credit.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_NAME: General Biology for the Environment and Life
CRS_DESC: Study of common skills in biology, including basics of evolution, systematics, ecology, genetics, biochemistry and molecular biology, physiology, and anatomy.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab.

CRS_DESC: Laboratory component for BISC 120 for entering freshmen or transfer students with advanced placement or equivalent lecture credit from another institution.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: To request d-clearance for this course, please visit dornsife.usc.edu/bisc/d-clearance-and-wait-list-information/

CRS_DESC: Laboratory component for BISC 220 for entering freshmen or transfer students with advanced placement or equivalent lecture credit from another institution.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: To request d-clearance for this course, please visit dornsife.usc.edu/bisc/d-clearance-and-wait-list-information/

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the scientific method; basic instruction in molecular biology with emphasis on how biological research advancement has impacted medicine, commerce and society in general.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for the lecture and one discussion.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of molecular biology, biochemistry, microbiology, nutrition and the history of biology through the study of food, focusing on food's relationship to the biological world.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab.

CRS_DESC: In-depth survey of key topics related to advances in our knowledge of the diversity of life and evolution; origin of life; eukaryotes/prokaryotes; ecology.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab. This course carries GE credit but it is intended for a specific group of students rather than a general student audience. It is part of the curriculum for majors and pre-professional students.

CRS_DESC: Changes in the physical and biological universe over time; origins of life, dinosaurs, human evolution. Implications of evolutionary mechanisms and mass extinctions for human survival.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: A series of lectures and discussions at which faculty of the department introduce their research activities to students entering biology and related majors.
Introduction to research activities conducted by Neuroscience faculty at USC.

In-depth survey of key topics related to advances in our knowledge of cellular biology and physiology; cell composition/metabolism; gene action; organism structure and function. Recommended preparation: high school chemistry; BISC 120L or BISC 121L.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture, one lab and the quiz section 13120. This course carries GE credit but is intended for a specific group of students rather than a general student audience. It is part of the curriculum for majors and pre-professional students. Final exam date: Tues May 07, 8:00-10:00 a.m.

CRS_DESC: Equivalent to 220L, but taught at a higher level for exceptionally well-prepared students. Admission to the course by departmental approval only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121)
  • Corequisite: 1 from (CHEM 105b or CHEM 115b)
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab. This course carries GE credit but is intended for a specific group of students rather than a general student audience. It is part of the curriculum for majors and pre-professional students. Section 13192 is a "SEA PHAGES" Genomics research section. Sections 13191, 13193 and 13194 are Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) sections. Enrollment in this course is limited to students admitted into the Freshman Science Honors (FSH) program.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of the unique properties of brain cells that allow complex perceptions and behaviors; examination of structure and activity of brain cells that underlie function.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Experience in basic techniques through supervised research in the research laboratory of a departmental faculty member.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 105B or CHEM 108 or CHEM 115B)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 105B or CHEM 108 or CHEM 115B)

CRS_DESC: Comparative approach to bacteria, Archaea and viruses; their structure, life cycles, geochemical activity, ecology and nutrition. Fundamentals of metabolism and microbial genetics.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 120 or BISC 121 or BISC 220 or BISC 221 or BISC 320)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121 or BISC 220 or BISC 221 or BISC 320)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab.

CRS_DESC: Physiological functions of the circulatory, digestive, endocrine, integuementary, musculoskeletal, nervous, respiratory, and urogenital systems in animals. Lecture, 3 hours; Laboratory, 3 hours.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Introduction to general statistical theory with higher-level mathematics for biological data analysis. Basic programming in R. Discussion of techniques to describe, visualize and model different types of data.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the QBIO department but may qualify for major credit in BISC. To register, enroll in QBIO 310.

CRS_DESC: Structure and function of biological macromolecules; major metabolic pathways including glycolysis and photosynthesis. DNA replication, repair, and recombination; gene expression, regulation and epigenetics.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Not available for major credit. Final exam date: Tues. May 13, 4:30-6:30 p.m.

CRS_DESC: History of evolutionary thought; molecular basis for evolution; dynamics of genes in populations; specialization and macroevolution; patterns of evolution. Recommended preparation: BISC-320, BISC-325, and familiarity with algebra, basic chemistry, and basic physics.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (BISC 120 or BISC 121)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Builds upon a basic science background to provide students with an awareness of cutting edge scientific research, its technological applications and its societal ramifications.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 120 or BISC 121 or BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 105A or CHEM 107 or CHEM 115A) and (PHYS 135A or PHYS 151)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121 or BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 105A or CHEM 107 or CHEM 115A) and 1 from (PHYS 135A or PHYS 151)

CRS_DESC: Basic biochemical principles; classes of molecules - structure and function; cellular energetics.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (CHEM 322A or CHEM 325A)
  • Note: Register for lecture, one lab and the quiz section. Final exam date: Tues. May 13, 4:30-6:30 p.m.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the morphology, classification, distribution and physiology of mammals; study of major mammalian groups worldwide and identification and field study of local species.
Application of modern field techniques to monitor mammalian biodiversity; quantification of biodiversity using museum-based collections and geospatial data; multi-day field trips.
Introduction to the experiments, theories and knowledge of modern cell biology; analysis of cutting-edge research papers; focused on organelles, signaling, cytoskeleton and the cell cycle.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Computational Analysis of Biological Data
CRS_DESC: A project-based course integrating biology, computer science, and statistics through the analysis of genomic datasets available publicly or collected and sequenced during the semester.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the QBIO department but may qualify for major credit in BISC. To register, enroll in QBIO 401.

CRS_DESC: Fundamental concepts of RNA biology and state-of-the-art biotechnologies using RNA for medical and industrial applications; CRISPR/Cas genome editing; therapeutic advances exploiting RNA biology.

Introduction to community ecology, macroecology, biodiversity and ecosystem functions, and current debates on trends in biodiversity; concepts include ecological theory, modeling, data management and analysis.

An examination of individual nerve cell development, target location, and establishment of functional synapses; how dysfunction in these processes contributes to neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: BISC 421
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion.

CRS_DESC: Sensory and motor systems to illustrate concepts regarding the functional organization of the brain, from microcircuitry of neural circuits to global processes such as perception. Prerequisite: BISC 421.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: BISC 421
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion.

CRS_NAME: Applications of Molecular Biology to Medicine
CRS_DESC: Advances and trends in the understanding, diagnosis and treatment of human diseases.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 312 or BISC 330 or CHEM 350)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior

CRS_DESC: The synthesis, transport and assembly of the complex structures that mediate eukaryotic cellular function. Electrical and biochemical mechanisms underlying intercellular communication.

Fundamentals of climate including atmosphere and ocean. Topics include radiative energy balance, ocean-atmosphere linkages and approaches to study climate while building quantitative and qualitative skills.
CRS_NOTE:
• Corequisite: MATH 125 and 1 from (CHEM 105A or CHEM 103)
  • Restriction: Registration closed to the following class level(s): Freshmen
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the GEOL department but may qualify for major credit in BISC. To register, enroll in GEOL 412.
  • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_DESC: Focus on the advances in molecular biology of cancer, from fundamental molecular signaling pathways to DNA repair to stem cell biology, through primary research literature reviews.
Examination of various neurological disorders originating from developmental signaling and/or anatomical abnormalities.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: BISC 421
  • Note: This course requires instructor permission to enroll.

CRS_DESC: How the parts of the brain are interconnected to form a complex biological computer, from historical, evolutionary and developmental perspectives.
Earth's development as a habitable planet, from origin to human impacts on global biogeochemical cycles in the ocean, land, atmosphere. Discussion of environmental alternatives.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 103 or BISC 120 or BISC 121) and (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105B or CHEM 108 or CHEM 115B)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 103 or BISC 120 or BISC 121) and 1 from (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105B or CHEM 108 or CHEM 115B)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Biological Sciences, Environmental Science and Health, Environmental Studies, Geological Sciences

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the habitat, phylogenetic, physiological and metabolic diversity of microbial life in aquatic environments.
Macromolecular structure and function; enzymology; metabolic regulation. Lecture, 3 hours; discussion, 2 hours.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: BISC 330
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion.

CRS_DESC: Consideration of the biological and social-cultural factors that govern the evolution of life spans and the life of humans and selected animal models. Recommended preparation: statistics
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121)
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the GERO department but may qualify for major credit in BISC. To register, enroll in GERO 440.

CRS_DESC: Fundamentals of protein engineering and its biotechnological applications in medicine, chemical processes and energy; methods for engineering biological molecules and designing protein engineering strategies.

CRS_NAME: Methods in Marine Biology and Biological Oceanography
CRS_DESC: Introduction to standard methods used in oceanography and marine biology through a a combination of lectures, laboratory exercises and field experiences.

CRS_NAME: Seminar in Marine and Environmental Biology
CRS_DESC: Topical seminar in marine and environmental biology. Junior, senior or graduate standing.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Master Student, Doctoral Student

CRS_NAME: Seminar in Molecular and Computational Biology
CRS_DESC: Topical seminar in molecular and computational biology. Junior, senior or graduate standing.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Master Student, Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Topical seminar in neurobiology.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Master Student, Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Exploration of the complex interactions between the nervous and immune systems, and disorders encompassing both neuroscience and immunology. Topics include autoimmunity, cancer, neurodevelopment, neuroimmunological treatments.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)

CRS_DESC: Oceanography and marine biology, sampling techniques, evolutionary adaptations, morphology, systematics.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 103 or BISC 120 or BISC 121)
  • Note: This class includes a mandatory weekend field trip to Catalina Island on February 21-23, 2025. All transportation and costs will be covered. Students that have a perceived conflict with this field trip must contact Dr. Heidelberg for permission to register.

CRS_DESC: Instruction in basic concepts and evolutionary mechanisms of animal and human development. Emphasis on molecular, genetic and cellular processes underlying vertebrate and invertebrate development.
Foundational skill-building for modeling and analysis of biological data. Hands-on instruction for developing and simulating models of dynamic biological systems.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the QBIO department but may qualify for major credit in BISC. To register, enroll in QBIO 482.

CRS_DESC: Relationships between microbiota and the earth environment including the hydrosphere, lithosphere and atmosphere, with consideration of the potential for life on other planets.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and (CHEM 105B or CHEM 108)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and 1 from (CHEM 105B or CHEM 108)

CRS_NAME: Advanced Seminar in Bacterial Survival and Evolution
CRS_DESC: Literature-based seminar in current topics in microbial evolution and adaptation.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (BISC 312 or BISC 320 or CHEM 350) and (CHEM 322A or CHEM 325A)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (BISC 312 or BISC 320 or CHEM 350) and 1 from (CHEM 322A or CHEM 325A)

CRS_DESC: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CRS_DESC: Not available for graduate credit.

CRS_DESC: Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: BISC 493
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior

CRS_DESC: Current genetic and biochemical analysis of replication, recombination, mutagenesis, and repair. Fundamentals of transcription and regulation of gene expression. Recent applications of genetic engineering and genome analysis.

CRS_NAME: Laboratory Techniques in Cellular and Molecular Biology
CRS_DESC: Rotation of graduate students through molecular biology research laboratories to learn the major technological skills required in the field. Graded CR/NC.
Introduction to the concept of symbiosis, exploration of mechanisms underpinning the ecology and evolution of these relationships, synthesis of key concepts in contemporary symbiosis research.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Advanced training for molecular biology graduate students in reading primary journal articles. Emphasis on critical analyses of primary scientific literature.

• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Computational Biology and Bioinformatics, Computational Molecular Biology, Molecular Biology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: Current topics in integrative and evolutionary biology.

Hands-on experience writing and reviewing scientific proposals from faculty and peers. For MEBP, GEOL and OCS students only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Geological Sciences, Biology (Marine and Environmental Biology), Ocean Sciences
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Survey of statistical techniques for research and analysis; foundations, underlying assumptions and the power and limitations of such statistical approaches.

CRS_DESC: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within College disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College.

• Note: Course not available for degree credit
  • Concurrent enrollment: CHEM 105A

CRS_DESC: Basic chemistry and its impact on the contemporary world. Topics include: structures and reactions of molecules, stoichiometry, nomenclature, gases, solutions.

• Prerequisite: CHEM 050

CRS_NOTE:
• Corequisite: 1 from (CHEM 430B or CHEM 431)
  • Note: Register for lecture-discussion and lab

CRS_NAME: Advanced Laboratory Techniques in Organic and Inorganic Chemistry

• Prerequisite: CHEM 300 and 1 from (CHEM 322b or CHEM 325b)
  • Note: Register for lecture, lab and disc

CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: PHYS 152
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_NAME: Physical Chemistry for the Life Sciences
CRS_DESC: Principles of physical chemistry relevant for the life sciences: thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, molecular dynamics, kinetics, molecular structures and interactions, spectroscopy, statistical thermodynamics and macromolecular structures. Duplicates credit in CHEM 430a.

CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (CHEM 300 or CHEM 322a or CHEM 325a) and MATH 126 and 1 from (PHYS 135a or PHYS 151)
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

• Prerequisite: 1 from (CHEM 322A or CHEM 325A)
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: The importance of plastics in daily life, the consequential effects on the environment and directions for sustainable solutions.

• Prerequisite: 1 from (CHEM 322A or CHEM 325A)
  • Note: Register for lecture and Lab

• Prerequisite: 1 from (CHEM 322A or CHEM 325A)

A survey of representative groups of widely used synthetic organic reactions; emphasis on scope, limitations, and stereochemical consequences.
Theoretical and experimental methods of molecular spectroscopy and applications to chemistry. Rotational, vibrational, electronic, electron and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopies.

Study of macroscopic systems from molecular viewpoint using statistical mechanics: ensembles, fluctuations, gases, gas-solid interfaces, crystals, polymers, critical phenomena, non-equilibrium systems.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

• Prerequisite: 1 from (EE 520 or PHYS 558A)

CRS_DESC: The philosophical foundations of modern political and economic thought, including economic rationality, neoclassical economics, free-market vs. socialist economies and behavioral economics.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PHIL department but may qualify for major credit in ECON. To register, enroll in PHIL 101.

  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Decision-making by business firms, consumer preferences and behavior, uncertainty, competition, monopoly, labor and resource markets, efficient resource allocation, externalities, and government policy.

CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (ECON 203 and ECON 205) and (MATH 118 or MATH 125)

CRS_DESC: Introduction to statistical methods appropriate for analyzing economic data: probability theory, random variables and probability distributions, sampling, estimation, statistical inference.
Application of statistical methods to economic data: estimating economic relationships using regression analysis, testing hypotheses involving economic behavior, forecasting economic variables.
Analyze varied industries using legal, business, and economic principles. Emphasis is on how these forces shape marketing strategies.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ECON 203 or ECON 351 or BUAD 351)
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the MKT department but may qualify for major credit in ECON. To register, enroll in MKT 333.

CRS_DESC: Central topics in the philosophy of economics, including models of economic rationality, the aggregation of preferences and the conditions in which markets yield undesirable outcomes.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PHIL department but may qualify for major credit in ECON. To register, enroll in PHIL 339.

CRS_DESC: Causes of economic underdevelopment: historical, institutional, structural, ideological, technological, cultural. Patterns and theories of development. Role of government, international trade, and education in economic growth.
A focus on the Chinese economy, its reform and transition to a market economy, its relation with East Asian countries and integration into the world economy.

Development and business applications of: theory of the firm; theory of the consumer; inter-temporaldecisions; decisions under risk; market failures; industrial and enterprise structure. Prerequisites: MATH 118 or MATH 125 or MATH 126 or MATH 226. Not for major credit for: Economics, Economics/Mathematics, Social Sciences (Economics). Duplicates credit in BUAD 351.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (MATH 118 or MATH 125 or MATH 126 or MATH 226)

CRS_DESC: Theoretical development and significance to business and markets of economic growth; inflation;unemployment; monetary and fiscal policy; business cycles; savings and investment; exchange rates. Corequisite: ECON 351. Recommended preparation: introductory economics course, high school math, and algebra. Not for major credit for: Economics, Economics/Mathematics, Social Sciences (Economics). Duplicates credit in BUAD 352.
The money, bond, stock, and other financial markets; portfolio choice; determinants of asset prices and interest rates; inflation; interactions between financial markets and government policies.
Key facts and basic mechanisms concerning financial crises and related topics (bank runs, sovereign default decision, currency collapse).

Main frameworks, theories, practices of applied economics policy in real-world settings; creating competencies for elected officials, central bank personnel, public administrators, regulators, nonprofit executives, implementers and evaluators.
Selected policy dilemmas in economics. Topics vary.

Analysis of strategic economic interactions. Topics include bargaining, insurance, patents, voting, environment depletion, strategic trade, learning, reputation, strikes, corporate takeovers, and the provision of public goods.
Introduction to the methodology used in experimental neuroeconomics and discussion of neural correlates of decision-making. Prerequisite: ECON 303.
Detailed discussion of economic models, including models of health, addiction, demand for healthcare and demand for insurance.
Examination of the traditional and behavioral theories of decision-making and the state of the art in the field. Prerequisite: ECON 303.
Factors that make values an essential feature of human society; how values develop, change and are abandoned; role of values in economic development.

General equilibrium analysis of economics with financial markets; decision making under uncertainty; methods of risk reduction; portfolio theory and valuation of securities; efficiency of security markets.

CRS_NAME: Economic Consulting and Applied Managerial Economics
CRS_DESC: Economic consulting and managerial economic methods applied in real world problems. Economic methods to analyze issues of intellectual property, environmental damage, trademark infringement, brand value, and consumer demand.
Management and extraction of renewable and non-renewable natural resources; environmental externalities and regulation of air, water, and land pollution; market incentives versus direct regulation.
Supervised individual research. Not available for graduate credit. Requires departmental approval.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Individual research supervised by a faculty advisor. Successful completion required for departmental honors degree.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: Theories of the household and the firm; product and factor markets; perfect and imperfect competition; welfare criteria.
Theories of aggregate economic activity; design and use of macroeconometric models; stabilization and control of inflation, unemployment, and growth.

CRS_NAME: Game Theory with Economic and Financial Applications
CRS_DESC: Applying game theory to economic and financial markets and interactions in a diverse set of examples like reputation, herding, bubbles and crashes, auctions, strategic information revelation and information accumulation in markets. Witnessing the wide range of applications that is amenable to game theoretical analysis.
Application of econometric tools using standard econometric software packages for microcomputers; empirical applications to selected economic problems of estimation and inference.

Understanding and implementing models commonly used in time series econometrics. Emphasis is placed on intuition and application. Assists students understanding how to use time series data to test hypotheses and serve as an introduction to the ideas and techniques of forecasting.
The balance of payments, macroeconomic policy in an open economy, exchange rate determination, exchange rate systems, currency crises, international financial arrangements and monetary history.
Introduction and exploration of quantitative methods and data sources used for applied trade policy analysis.
How do investors evaluate risks? With what information? How do they form their beliefs? Via empirical evidence and theoretical works, this course addresses these questions.
Introduction to the theory and practice of causal econometrics in modern settings of large-scale data. Major algorithms from machine learning focused on methodology and applications.
Introduces the novel business model and important features associated with digital platforms and analyzes firms various competitive behavior and anticompetitive conducts in the digital space.

Broad training in theoretical and empirical finance. Choice under uncertainty; equilibrium asset pricing; static portfolio choice; factor pricing models, asset allocation; the Black-Scholes-Merton Formula.
Efficiency, market failure, government regulation, some basics for antitrust economics, competition policy analysis and collusion and agreements among competitors.
Economic methods to analyze issues of intellectual property, environmental damage, trademark infringement, brand value and consumer demand, using an applied econometric approach.
The role of designing incentives to reduce negative urban externalities and the interplay between spatial Big Data and testing urban economics hypotheses.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. Students must have a specific job/internship offer. Job must be related to students major. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. Students must have been in F-1 student status for at least one academic year in a degree-seeking program before they can apply for CPT, with a cumulative 3.0 GPA. Course does not apply to degree credit. Open only to graduate students.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: General equilibrium theory; existence, uniqueness, and stability; welfare economics; social choice; dynamic models and uncertainty; special topics. Prerequisite: ECON-601.

Macroeconomic theory based on the concepts of optimal growth and intertemporal equilibrium; overlapping generations models; recent developments in macroeconomic theory. Prerequisites: ECON-601 and ECON-602.
Examination of behavioral theories used to describe and predict choices made in both an individual decision-making setting and strategic environments.

Review of statistical methods of estimation and inference, linear regression with multicollinearity and serial correlation; multivariate regression and simultaneous equations. Prerequisite: ECON 611. Duplicates credit in former ECON 511.
Use of quantitative models to describe and forecast economic activity; estimation and application of such models to selected policy problems. Prerequisites: ECON 609.
Experimental methods relying on non-choice data. Design methods of experiments that record information in decision-making and physiological data of emotions.
The functions of laws, rules, customs, conventions, and other restrictions on economic and social activity. Theories of institutional evolution. Prerequisites: ECON-500 or ECON-601.

Theory and empirics of the sources of and barriers to economic development and the micro underpinnings of macroeconomic dynamics of growth, inequality, and productivity. Prerequisites: ECON 601 and ECON 609.
Current areas of research in macroeconomics: Structural Change; Inequality and Macroeconomics.
Think about and design empirical studies in economics using cutting-edge approaches to causal inference -- structural and discrete choice models, micro-macro models and historical data models.
Current research in economic theory presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.
Current research in econometrics presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.
Current research in international, regional, and urban development economics presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: Study of African migration to Europe and the formation of 'black'/African communities in Europe, focusing on France and Italy. Conducted in English.

• Prerequisite: FREN 250

CRS_DESC: Advanced composition through critical reading of literary texts; comprehensive analysis of difficult grammatical structures and stylistics. Prerequisite: FREN 300.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of experimental artistic collaborations between poets, novelists,art critics and artists of the Paris Avant-gardes in 19th and 20th Century. Taught in French. Paris Semester. Prerequisite: FREN 300. Corequisite: FREN 330.

CRS_DESC: Geologic structure and evolution of planet earth. Principles ofplate tectonics, rocks and minerals, processes of mountainbuilding, continent and ocean formation, earthquakes, volcanism,development of landforms by running water and glaciers. Lecture, 3hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day or two-day field triprequired.

• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Physical, chemical, and geological character of the oceans andocean basins. Origin of the oceans. Ocean processes and agents.Economic value of the oceans. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day field trip required.

• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Impact of civilization on planet earth, and impact of earth's natural evolution on society: earthquakes, volcanism, landslides, floods, global warming, acid rain, groundwater depletion and pollution; mineral and fossil fuel depletion, formation of the ozone hole. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day or overnight field trip.

• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

Provides a framework for students in history and neighboring fields to conduct research based on primary source materials and the relevant historical literature.
Selected topics in the history of the American frontier and the West.
Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: HIST 794A
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: HIST 794B
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: HIST 794C
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Human and Evolutionary Biology
CRS_DESC: Introduction to the major and field of human and evolutionary biology; sub-disciplines, career options and areas for research; guest speakers.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Human Biology
  • Note: Please contact your *freshman* advisor if you need clearance. Do not fill out a d-clearance request form!

CRS_DESC: Foundations of the human species. Examination of scientific evidence from Darwinian theory, primate behavior, fossils, and the behavior of modern people. Laboratory. Duplicates credit in former ANTH 200Lg.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: To develop an understanding of Nutrition, especially as it pertains to optimal health and prevention of diseases. A study of macro and micro nutrients.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one LECTURE and one LAB with the same session number

CRS_DESC: The physiological and nutritional basis of human performance. Factors that facilitate and limit athletic achievement. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. Not available for major credit. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 205Lxg.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one LECTURE and one LAB.

CRS_DESC: Major organ systems; functional implications of their relationships; gross and microscopic examination with an emphasis on practical skills in recognizing, dissecting, and differentiating anatomical structures. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 301L.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for1 lecture and one LAB with the same session number.

CRS_DESC: Gastrointestinal physiology and energy metabolism as it relates to macronutrient intake. Theories and principles of nutrition and their impact on metabolic regulation. Prerequisites: BISC 220L or BISC 221L. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 200.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Note: To request d-clearance: forms.gle/mo8nCefH9kmiteUN9

CRS_DESC: Behavior and ecology of living nonhuman primates, with an emphasis on field studies of apes and monkeys. Topics include aggression, communication, reproduction and cognition.
Analysis of the skeletal muscular system (anatomy, physiology, biochemistry, and development) and its functional properties under both normal and pathological conditions.

An overview of the genetic underpinning of human health and disease. Inheritance of mendelian diseases, common diseases, developmental diseases and cancer; prenatal testing, genetic counseling and genetic therapies.
Theories of control and learning applied to motor performance; variables affecting performance in exercise, games, sports and dance.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Terminology, structure and function of muscle, bone and endocrine systems; Effects of exercise and training on those systems.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Evolutionary, cultural, and environmental factors in the emergence and existence of diseases; a Darwinian examination of illness in the human species.

CRS_NAME: Theory and Method in Human Evolutionary Biology
CRS_DESC: Historical and theoretical approaches to major issues in the field of human evolutionary biology. Capstone course in which students will undertake an original independent research project.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: HBIO 200
  • Restriction: Registration closed to the following class level(s): Freshmen, Junior, Sophomore

CRS_DESC: Regulation of metabolic pathways and endocrinology in health and metabolic diseases.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: HBIO 302
  • Restriction: Registration closed to the following class level(s): Freshmen, Junior, Sophomore
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Examination of the etiology, prevention, and treatment of metabolic disorders such as diabetes mellitus and obesity that are major threats to public health.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Restriction: Registration closed to the following class level(s): Freshmen, Junior, Sophomore
  • Note: To be added to the d-clearance waitlist, please fill out this form: forms.gle/8fMZQTwjx6w5Ev1f9

CRS_DESC: The physiology of the respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, musculoskeletal, digestive, endocrine and nervous systems in humans, with application to human health and pathology.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: HBIO 301 and 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_NAME: Neurobiology of Feeding Behavior and Obesity
CRS_DESC: Neurobiological systems that control feeding behavior and energy balance with an emphasis on the determinants of obesity.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Note: To be added to the d-clearance waitlist, please fill out this form: forms.gle/8fMZQTwjx6w5Ev1f9

CRS_NAME: Evaluation and Rehabilitation of Athletic Injuries
CRS_DESC: Application of scientific principles to evaluating and rehabilitating athletic injuries.

Practical laboratory experience in basic and applied exercise physiology, biochemistry, and/or biomechanics. Emphasizing development of laboratory techniques. Prerequisites: HBIO 203, HBIO 301, HBIO 302, HBIO 320. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 491.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (HBIO 203 or HBIO 301 or HBIO 302 or HBIO 320)

CRS_DESC: Small group investigation from an interdisciplinary perspective.
Research and Study with LAS Faculty Associates and other faculty.
In-service experience in a variety of off-campus institutions under the supervision of an LAS Faculty Associate.
Small group investigation from an interdisciplinary perspective.
Research and study with LAS Faculty Associates and other faculty.
In-service experience in a variety of off-campus institutions under the supervision of an LAS Faculty Associate.
Small group investigation from an interdisciplinary perspective.
Research and study with LAS Faculty Associates and other faculty.
In-service experience in a variety of off-campus institutions under the supervision of an LAS Faculty Associate.
Writing the IDM senior thesis under the supervision of a faculty guidance committee.

Basic concepts of world affairs for non-majors. Development ofcompetency to understand and critically evaluate global relationsand international events, stressing empirical approaches. Not available for major credit.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of the major social, political, economic, religious, and philosophical disagreements that exist between scholars, leaders, and citizens concerning today's most serious environmental issues and problems. Not available for credit to environmental studies majors and minors.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the ENST department but may qualify for major credit in IR. To register, enroll in ENST 150.

CRS_DESC: Comprehensive introduction to contending theoretical and analytical approaches; development of critical, evaluative, cognitive, and analytical competencies regarding historical and contemporary issues.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion. This course carries GE credit but it is intended for a specific group of students rather than a general student audience. International Relations majors and minors can obtain D-clearance through the department.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to theoretically oriented research approaches and designs; emphasis on the logic of argumentation.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: Introduction to historical research methods with an emphasis on historical texts and modes of discourse.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for one lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: Economic and political concepts necessary to the understanding of the modern global economy. Topics include international trade, foreign investment and migration.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for one lecture and discussion

CRS_NAME: National Intelligence and the Shaping of Policy
CRS_DESC: The focus is intelligence to improve the making of policy, with attention to collection; overt and covert, operations; domestic intelligence; and oversight in democracies.
Interdisciplinary study of the pursuit of peace, including causes of wars, arms races, conflict resolution, peace movements, nonviolent resistance, and peace with justice.
An introduction to debates about the intersection of religion and conflict in politics and international affairs; theoretical, classical, and contemporary issues.

CRS_NAME: Ethnicity and Nationalism in World Politics
CRS_DESC: Ethnic identity and nation formation in the global society of states; nation-states; conflict or political accommodation within multinational states; impact of dispersed nations on interstate relations.
Explore causes of human security, international responses to issues like violence, displacement and climate change; and the costs, benefits and effects of humanitarian intervention.
Impact of technological advances to global security and development. Focus on surveillance and cyber conflict; nuclear weaponry, aviation and UAVs missiles and BMD; submarines and ASW.

Examines the politics of managing the global environment. The nature of ecosystems, commons problems, population and resource utilization problems along with biodiversity and global governance are emphasized.

CRS_NAME: North-South Relations in the Global Economy
CRS_DESC: Analysis of inequality in relations between developed and developing states; contending views on the causes and legacies of imperialism; development strategies and aid.

CRS_NAME: The Global Finance and Monetary Regime
CRS_DESC: The international financial and monetary regime, its evolution and the problems facing it today
Exploration of questions and concepts in international economics and politics, especially as they relate to flows of trade, capital, people, and problems across borders.
Examination of key ideas from economics, demography and technology. Guest lecturers illuminate possible conditions of the Global Economy in 2040.
Introduction to the relationship between economics, security, and U.S. foreign policy. Topics covered: U.S. grand strategy, Chinas rise, energy security, resource competition, and the resource curse.

CRS_NAME: The Politics and Strategy of Weapons of Mass Destruction
CRS_DESC: Causes and effects of use and spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons; responses to WMD, including deterrence, preventive war, and non-proliferation policies and negotiations.

CRS_NAME: U.S. Foreign Policy Since World War II
CRS_DESC: Analysis of U.S. foreign policy since 1945 as a basis for understanding significant new trends. Explanation of contemporary issues in U.S. relations with other nations.

CRS_NAME: The Global South in World Politics
CRS_DESC: Origin, concepts, realities and ideals of the non-aligned movement, focusing on the role of the United States in the developing world.

CRS_NAME: International Relations of the Pacific Rim
CRS_DESC: Political, economic and security relations among the countries in East Asia and the Pacific with the emphasis on the role of the United States, China and Japan.

CRS_NAME: The International Relations of the Contemporary Middle East
CRS_DESC: Introduction to problems and issues in the Middle East today: religio-ethnic rivalries, conflicting nationalisms and ideologies, the Arab-Israeli conflict, Middle East oil.

CRS_NAME: Politics and Democracy in Latin America
CRS_DESC: Examines Latin America's experience with democracy emphasizing events since the 1980s. Analyzes the roles of interest groups, ideology, domestic politics, bureaucratic processes, perceptions and analogical reasoning.

CRS_NAME: Mexico and its Relations with the United States
CRS_DESC: Analysis of Mexico and U.S.-Mexico relations, both historically and in the present day, to understand better the challenges in this key bilateral relationship.
General overview of main historical, political, and economic issues as they affect Africa, focusing on nationalism, development, and superpower competition in Africa.
Introduction to historical, thematic perspectives of French foreign policy since 1945 including review of external and internal constraints influencing foreign policy. (Paris semester only).

Examination of diplomatic and moral relationships between sovereign states and transnational non-state actors, both benevolent (humanitarian groups and philanthropies) and malevolent (mercenaries, pirates and terrorists).

CRS_NAME: Order and Disorder in Global Affairs
CRS_DESC: Modern and post-modern perspectives on changes in the inter-state system, relations among cultures and civilizations, the conditions of ecologically sustainable human development.
Focuses on the international politics of resolving crises. Application of theories of conflict and negotiation in a UN Security Council Simulation.
(Paris Semester only) Historical overview of interactions between Muslims and Europeans. Islam: origins, history and circumstances that led to its revival. France's immigration policy.
Intensive internship experience in international relations professional areas with academic research component (may be repeated for credit different semesters)
The domestic and international sources of Chinese foreign policy; political, military, and economic issues in China's relations with its neighbors.

CRS_NAME: Environment and Politics in the Middle East
CRS_DESC: Introduction to key environmental and political challenges facing the contemporary Middle East and North Africa (MENA).
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the MDES department but may qualify for major credit in IR. To register, enroll in MDES 401.

CRS_NAME: Applied Data Science for International Relations 2
CRS_DESC: Intermediate statistical computing and data visualization in R. Focus the on graphical presentation of complex statistical relationships. Students create publication-ready figures for actual faculty research projects.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: IR 210 and IR 211 and (IR 412 or IR 307)

CRS_DESC: Examines causes, consequences and how to combat corruption as an economic, political and social problem.

Should environmental issues be treated as threats to security? Survey of recent literature explores global environmental politics using a security framework. Recommended preparation: Environmental studies course work.
Introduction to important economic issue areas that are understood as security-related in the contemporary world: population, food, trade, debt, etc.
An interdisciplinary treatment of the tragic phenomenon of genocide. Subject matter includes historical cases and analysis of contemporary global efforts toward prevention.

Critical discussion of alternative approaches explaining the formulation and implementation of U.S. foreign policy: domestic politics, organizational processes, group dynamics, individual personality and perception.

Policies and programs aimed at stopping the spread of weapons of mass destruction (WMD). Presentations by executive/legislative officials involved in formulation and implementation of non-proliferation. Junior or senior standing required.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_NAME: Contemporary Issues in Latin American Politics
CRS_DESC: Focus on current politics in Latin America. Address a range of themes: electoral democracy, citizenship, political inclusion, human rights, corruption, economic inequality.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Selected topics in various special areas within international relations, which may vary from semester to semester or within semesters.
Explores cybersecurity, privacy, network neutrality and other critical issues in internet governance through the lenses of international political economy and media theories.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the COMM department but may qualify for major credit in IR. To register, enroll in COMM 553.

CRS_DESC: Continuation of Persian I. Prerequisite: IRAN 120. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 150)

Continuing Intermediate Persian (Farsi). Building conversational skills, listening and reading comprehension, grammar and vocabulary necessary for intermediate level spoken and written expression. Prerequisite: IRAN 220. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 250)
Continuation of Advanced Persian I. Prerequisite: IRAN 320. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 350)

English grammar as it relates to Italian in order to improve students' Italian language skills; explicit pronunciation and intonation practice. Requires concurrent enrollment in either ITAL 120 Italian I or MPVA 260 Italian Language and Diction.
Introduction to current Italian. Oral practice, hearing and reading comprehension; grammar necessary for simple spoken and written expression. Lecture, classroom drill, laboratory drill.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Students with previous exposure to Italian must take the Italian placement exam. D-clearance for Italian I is available at language.usc.edu. The date and time of the final exam for this course is TBA

CRS_DESC: Developing competence in listening, vocal pronunciation, speaking, singing, International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA), reading and writing Italian. Emphasizes musical texts including Italian song and operatic arias.
CRS_NOTE:
• Crosslist: This course is offered by the MPVA department but may qualify for major credit in ITAL. To register, enroll in MPVA 260.
  • Note: The department of Italian offers a complementary practicum, ITAL 012x,to improve students' Italian language skills while taking MPVA 260. If interested in taking ITAL 012x practicum, please contact an advisor in THH 155 or call 213-740-3700 for more details and D-clearance.

CRS_DESC: Continuation of Italian I.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ITAL 120 or MPVA 260)
  • Note: After the first week of classes, all sections will be converted from "R" to "D", requiring instructor approval. The date and time of the final exam for this course is TBA. While MPVA 260 counts as a prerequisite for ITAL 150, it does not count toward the Dornsife minimum unit requirement.

CRS_NAME: Accelerated Italian for Speakers of Spanish and Other Romance Languages
CRS_DESC: Accelerated introduction to written and spoken Italian for students with a high level of proficiency in Spanish or another Romance Language. Students completing this course may enroll in the third semester of the basic language sequence ITAL 220.
Continuation of Italian II. Review of structure of the language, drill in aural and reading comprehension, practice in oral expression.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ITAL 150 or ITAL 175)
  • Note: After the first week of classes, all sections will be converted from "R" to "D", requiring instructor approval. The date and time of the final exam for this course is TBA. PLEASE NOTE: SECTION #34457 IS A MAYMESTER COURSE IN ROME, ITALY.

CRS_DESC: Combined classroom discussion and supervised internship at companies. Practical experience in applying communication and cultural knowledge in a professional employment context.

Continuation of Italian III. Review and expand upon abilities to create with the language in concrete exchanges, descriptions, comparisons, questions and discussions relevant to current issues and topics.
Continuation of Italian IV. Extend and refine conversational skills in professional and academic environments. Provide richer narrations and descriptions of current events and public interest.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: ITAL 240
  • Note: Section 34460 is a Maymester offering in Venice, Italy.

CRS_DESC: Continuation of Italian V. Further perfect and nuance academic, familial, and professional conversations. Contribute and control topics in all major time frames with accuracy, clarity and precision.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: ITAL 250
  • Note: Section 34461 is a Maymester offering in Venice, Italy.

CRS_DESC: Study of African migration to Europe and the formation of 'black'/African communities in Europe, focusing on France and Italy. Conducted in English.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the FREN department but may qualify for major credit in ITAL. To register, enroll in FREN 270.

CRS_DESC: An interdisciplinary introduction to the literary, artistic, and political movements which contributed to the shaping of modern Italy. Taught in English.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_NAME: Gender and Sexuality in Renaissance Italy
CRS_DESC: Interdisciplinary exploration of gender and sexuality in Italian renaissance literature and visual arts by male and female authors and artists from the fourteenth through the sixteenth century.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Study and analysis of colonialism and postcolonialism in Italian contexts. Taught in Italian.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Major ideas, personalities, and movements in Jewish history from antiquity to the present in light of the interaction of the Jews with the general culture.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_NAME: Jewish Histories of the Modern Middle East
CRS_DESC: Explores Jewish participation in the social, cultural, political and economic life of the modern Middle East.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Exploring the Hebrew Bible, the world in which it arose, and influential texts, including work from Ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia and the Southern Levant.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Historical background and responses to the Holocaust, withspecial emphasis on ethical implications.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: History and contexts of anti-Semitism, racism and other discourses about difference examined through religious, national and cultural forms in Europe and in the US.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Sephardic Jews trace their ancestry to medieval Iberia and now comprise a global diaspora. Explore the creation and expansion of the Sephardic diaspora.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Investigates understandings of law, legal interpretation and the integration of law and narrative in Jewish texts by exploring how to examine legal and literary texts.
Investigates contemporary conflicts in the discovery of the ancient world. Students will ask essential questions about the power of discovering and showcasing specific narratives.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Examination of the social forces that shaped and continue to shape culture and society in contemporary Israel.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary.
Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary, continued. Basic reading skills.
Reading Latin literature. Introduction to reading and translation of classical Latin prose and poetry. Extensive grammar review.
Studies in the Aeneid or Eclogues and Georgics.
Words as tools for discovering properties of the human mind. How words are formed of and form various units. Experiments exploring judgments about word interpretation.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Discourse patterns among diverse social groups in institutional and interpersonal settings; interrelationships among language practices and gender, socioeconomic status, ethnicity; social structures and cultural values as reflected in language policies and practices.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Familiarization with ASL and fingerspelling. Covers visual and gestural communication, comprehension through receptive language skills, basic conversational proficiency, general insights into American Deaf culture.
Increased development of inflectional and non-manual behavior patterns presented with incorporation of selected aspects of Deaf culture and community within receptive and expressive conversations.
Empirical study of the sounds and structures of human language;syntax and semantics; language change; linguistic universals.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Study of human linguistic competence and technologies that simulate it. Phonetics, vibration and signal processing, speech recognition, neural networks.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_DESC: A survey of topics in phonology and morphology.
Advanced study of topics in syntax.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: (LING 302 and LING 210)
  • Note: A waiver of prerequisite can be granted after consultation with the instructor

CRS_DESC: Language and society: theory and methods in sociolinguistics; dimensions of language variation including gender, identity, class, age, region; personal-level interactions to national-level language policies.
Theories of second language acquisition in children and adults; comparison of first and second language acquisition including psychological, social, and individual factors.
Familiarization with the articulation and transcription of speech sounds. Also vocal tract anatomy, acoustics, speech technology, non-English sounds, perception. Includes laboratory exercises.
Principles of cognitive development, learning, and motivation applied to the development of literacy; includes tutoring a child 2 hours per week. Prerequisite: PSYC 336L.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: PSYC 336
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PSYC department but may qualify for major credit in LING. To register, enroll in PSYC 433.

CRS_DESC: Topics of current interest at the crossroads of philosophy of language, philosophy of mind and linguistics.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PHIL department but may qualify for major credit in LING. To register, enroll in PHIL 467.

CRS_DESC: Elicitation techniques and methodological principles; recording and analysis of phonological, syntactic and semantic structures; practical approaches to procedures used in urban and rural settings.
Introduction to modern neural network approaches to natural language processing, based on Deep Learning. Recursive and recurrent neural networks; backpropagation; Ngram models.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Writing of the honors thesis. Registration is restricted to honors students.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration closed to the following major(s): Linguistics

CRS_DESC: Professional development in phonetics and phonology. Skills workshops, discussion of emerging research in the literature, and internal and external presentations of work in progress.
Professional development in syntax and semantics. Skills workshops, discussion of emerging research in the literature, and internal and external presentations of work in progress.
Professional development in psycholinguistics. Skills workshops, discussion of emerging research in the literature, and internal and external presentations of work in progress.
Traditional views of phonology; generative phonology; current developments in phonological research and theory.
Principles and comparison of modern theories of grammar with special reference to syntax.
Intensive work in semantic theory, in preparation for a research specialization in the area.
Recording and analysis of a living language as employed by a native speaker of that language.
Acquisition of grammatical, discourse, and conversational competence; strategies and structures.
Current issues in psycholinguistic theory.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

CRS_NAME: Seminar in Experimental Methods in Linguistics
CRS_DESC: Topics in quantitataive methods in linguistics research, e.g., covariance structure analysis, multi-dimensional scaling, log linear model, meta-analysis.
Readings in phonetic theory and current research as the framework for a discussion-oriented class.
Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
CRS_NOTE:
