  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Review of Algebra. Real numbers, linear equations and inequalities, functions, graphs, systems of equations, exponents, polynomials, factoring, rational expressions, radicals, quadratic equations and solutions. Graded CR/NC.
Equations and inequalities; functions; graphs; polynomial and rational functions; exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric function; analytic geometry.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 040
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: An introduction to the basic tools of statistics. Descriptive statistics; probability; expected value; normal approximation sampling; chance models; tests of significance. Recommended preparation: MATH 040x or math placement exam. Not available for major credit to Math students.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Mathematics for Business and Economics
CRS_DESC: Functions, graphs, polynomial and rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, matrices, systems of linear equations.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 040
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Derivatives and extrema. The definite integral and u-substitutions. Functions of several variables and their extrema; constrained optimization.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 108 or MATH 117)
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Limits; continuity, derivatives and applications; antiderivatives; the fundamental theorem of calculus; exponential and logarithmic functions.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 108
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: A continuation of MATH 125: trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 125
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_NAME: Calculus II for Engineers and Scientists
CRS_DESC: Trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates. Engineering and physics applications. Prerequisite: MATH 125. (Duplicates credit in MATH 126 and MATH 127)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 125
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Descriptive statistics, probability, discrete and continuous random variables, expectation and variance, sampling, Central Limit Theorem, estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression. Emphasis on health science. Prerequisite: MATH 118xg or MATH 125.

CRS_NAME: Linear Algebra and Linear Differential Equations
CRS_DESC: Matrices, systems of linear equations, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, systems of linear differential equations.
Vectors, vector valued functions; differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables; Green's theorem, Divergence theorem, Stoke's theorem.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 126 or MATH 127 or MATH 129)
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_NAME: Calculus III for Engineers and Scientists
CRS_DESC: A continuation of 129; vectors, vector valued functions; differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables; Greens theorem. Engineering and physics applications. Prerequisite: MATH 126, or MATH 127, or MATH 129.(Duplicates credit in MATH 226 and MATH 227)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 126 or MATH 127 or MATH 129)
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Matrices, systems of linear equations, vector spaces, inner products and norms, linear transformations, eigenvalues. Applications such as singular value decomposition, image compression, graphs, networks and linear programming.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 126 or MATH 127 or MATH 129)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_NAME: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering I
CRS_DESC: First-order differential equations; second-order linear differential equations; determinants and matrices; systems of linear differential equations; Laplace transforms.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 226 or MATH 227 or MATH 229)
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Preparation for reading and writing proofs with applications from major branches of mathematics, focusing on axiomatic structures and transformations that preserve structure.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 126 or MATH 127 or MATH 129)
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_NAME: Statistical Inference and Data Analysis II
CRS_DESC: Confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, p-values, likelihood ratio, nonparametrics, descriptive statistics, regression, multiple linear regression, experimental design, analysis of variance, categorical data, chi-squared tests, Bayesian statistics.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 307
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: Systematic approach to solving non-standard and competition level math problems on inequalities, infinite sums and products, combinatorics, number theory and games.

Probability spaces. Main families of discrete and continuous distributions and relations among them. Moments, characteristic functions, sequences of random variables, laws of large numbers, Central Limit Theorem.

Principles for testing hypotheses and estimation, confidence intervals, methods of moments, maximum likelihood, information inequality, likelihood ratio tests, goodness of fit and nonparametric methods.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 407
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Sets; relations; groups; homomorphisms; symmetric groups; Abelian groups; Sylow's theorems; introduction to rings and fields.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 290 or MATH 430 or MATH 432)
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: The real number system, metric spaces, limits, continuity, derivatives and integrals, infinite series.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 290 or MATH 430 or MATH 432)
  • Note: Register for one lecture and discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Implicit function theorems, Jacobians, transformations, multiple integrals, line integrals.
Introduction to the theory of numbers, including prime factorization, congruences, primitive roots, N-th power residues, number theoretic functions and certain diophantine equations.

Mathematical induction, counting principles, arrangements, selections, binomial coefficients, generating functions, recurrence relations, inclusion-exclusion, symmetric groups, graphs, Euler and Hamiltonian circuits, trees, graph algorithms; applications.
Vectors, elements of vector analysis, applications to curves and surfaces, standard material of differential geometry.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (MATH 226 or MATH 227 or MATH 229) and (MATH 225 or MATH 235 or MATH 245)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 226 or MATH 227 or MATH 229) and 1 from (MATH 225 or MATH 235 or MATH 245)

CRS_NAME: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering II
CRS_DESC: Vector field theory; theorems of Gauss, Green, and Stokes; Fourier series and integrals; complex variables; linear partial differential equations; series solutions of ordinary differential equations.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (MATH 245 or (MATH 225 and MATH 226) or (MATH 225 and MATH 227) or (MATH 225 and MATH 229))
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 245 or (MATH 225 and MATH 226) or (MATH 225 and MATH 227) or (MATH 225 and MATH 229))

CRS_DESC: Python implementations of: data collection, data wrangling, exploratory data analysis, dimensionality reduction, unsupervised / supervised learning, clustering, classification, common predictive statistical / machine learning algorithms, model validation.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: MATH 408 and (MATH 225 or MATH 235) and (ITP 115 or ITP 116)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: MATH 408 and 1 from (MATH 225 or MATH 235) and 1 from (ITP 115 or ITP 116)

CRS_DESC: Mathematical aspects of Machine Learning. PAC Learning, VC-dimension and complexity. Linear predictors (regression, perceptron, SVM). Convex learning and gradient descent. Neural networks and backpropagation.

Evolution of mathematical ideas and techniques as seen through a study of the contributions of eminent mathematicians to the formulation and solution of celebrated problems. Recommended preparation: upper division MATH course.

Rounding errors in digital computation; solution of linear algebraic systems; Newton's method for nonlinear systems; matrix eigenvalues; polynomial approximation; numerical integration; numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 225 or MATH 235 or MATH 245)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Formulation and study of models arising in population dynamics, growth of plankton, pollution of rivers, highway traffic, morphogenesis and tidal dynamics: stability, oscillations, bifurcations, chaos. The lab will consist of computer simulation of models using commercially available software.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 225 or MATH 245)
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: Polynomial rings, vector spaces, linear transformations, canonical forms, inner product spaces.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Theory of Complex Variables
CRS_DESC: Complex numbers and functions. Power series, analytic functions, harmonic functions. Complex integration, Cauchy's theorem, Cauchy's formula. Conformal mapping. Applications in physics and engineering.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Lectures on advanced material not covered in regularly scheduled courses. No more than two registrations allowed. Prerequisite: Departmental Approval.
Lectures directed to mathematics graduate students by faculty of the department and by outside speakers. Problem solving workshops. Graded CR/NC.

Linear equations and matrices, Gauss elimination, error estimates, iteration techniques; contractive mappings, Newton's method; matrix eigenvalue problems; least-squares approximation, Newton-Cotes and Gaussian quadratures; finite difference methods. Prerequisite: linear algebra and calculus.
Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear systems of equations; approximation theory using functional analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.
Markov processes in discrete or continuous time; renewal processes; martingales; brownian motion and diffusion theory; random walks, inventory models, population growth, queuing models, shot noise.

a: Probability spaces; distributions and characteristic functions; laws of large numbers, central limit problems; stable and infinitely divisible laws; conditional distributions. Prerequisite: 525a or 570. b: Dependence, martingales, ergodic theorems, second-order random functions, harmonic analysis, Markov processes.

B: Commutative Algebra: Integrality, Hilbert Basis theorem, Hilbert Nullstellensatz; Modules: modules over PID's, chain conditions, tensor products; Noncommutative Rings: Jacobson radical, Artin-Wedderburn theorem, Maschke's theorem.
Major parametric and non-parametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: PM 510
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PM department but may qualify for major credit in MATH. To register, enroll in PM 511a.

CRS_DESC: Statistical methods for analysis of categorical data including dichotomous, ordinal, multinomial and count data, using Stata package. Includes laboratory.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: PM 511A
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PM department but may qualify for major credit in MATH. To register, enroll in PM 511b.

CRS_DESC: Geometry of varieties and schemes including sheaf theory, morphisms of schemes, projective schemes, coherent and quasi-coherent sheaves, line bundles, and projective space.
Theory of analytic functions--power series and integral representations, calculus of residues, harmonic functions, normal families, approximation theorems, conformal mapping, analytical continuation.

a: Measure and integration over abstract measure spaces, Radon-Nikodym theorem, Fubini's theorem, convergence theorems, differentiation. Prerequisite: 425ab. b: Metric spaces, contraction principle, category, Banach spaces, Riesz representation theorem, properties of Lp, Hilbert spaces, orthogonal expansions, Fourier series and transforms, convolutions. Prerequisite: 525a.

Advanced topics in stochastic analysis, asset pricing in continuous time, stochastic control, Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations, incomplete markets, American options, exotic options, term structure of interest rates. Duplicates credit in the former MATH-506.

Combinatorics motivated by Representation Theory and Algebraic Geometry. Topics may include: representations of the symmetric group, symmetric functions, Young tableaux and plane partitions, permutation enumeration.

Elementary theory of manifolds, Lie groups, homogeneous spaces, fiber bundles and connections. Riemannian manifolds, curvature and conjugate points, second fundamental form, other topics. Prerequisite: 440.

Parametric families of distributions, sufficiency. Estimation: methods of moments, maximum likelihood, unbiased estimation. Comparison of estimators, optimality, information inequality, asymptotic efficiency. EM algorithm, jacknife and bootstrap.
Transfer function models; stationary, nonstationary processes; moving average, autoregressive models; spectral analysis; estimation of mean, autocorrelation, spectrum; seasonal time series.
Mathematical foundations of machine learning, machine learning algorithms, applications in financial forecasting, derivatives valuation and hedging, portfolio optimization.
Second-order partial differential equations of elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic type; in particular, potential and wave equations.

Existence, uniqueness and continuation of solutions, differential inequalities, linear systems, Sturm-Liouville theory, boundary value problems, Poincare-Bendixson theory, periodic solutions, perturbations, stability, fixed point techniques.

CRS_DESC: Students explore different understandings of work and career in American society while testing theories in an actual work setting.

CRS_DESC: An opportunity to acquire an intellectual skill in a small group setting.

CRS_DESC: A multidisciplinary exploration of the Armenian cultural heritage through the ages -- folklore, traditions, religious practices, literature, architecture, painting, sculpture, music, theater, film and dance.
Introduction to the cultural origins, history, art, literature, and films of South Asia, comprising Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India, the Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the BISC department but may qualify for major credit in NEUR. To register, enroll in BISC 407.

Improvement of body shape, muscle endurance, and muscle strength; understanding of weight training and nutrition principles that can be utilized for future weight training development.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Only first class meets in maps.usc.edu/?id=1928&reference=ped" target="_blank" class="map">PED210. Subsequent classes meet in the Lyons Center Cardinal Room. Students MUST have ID.

CRS_DESC: Basic instruction of self-defense for beginners; strategies for standing and ground fighting situations with and without weapons.
Intermediate instruction involving more advanced fighting strategies and techniques.

CRS_NAME: Principles of Self Defense and Personal Safety
CRS_DESC: Application of learned skills and strategies for identifying physical threats; increased situational awareness; understanding of when physical force may be required.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Only first class meets in maps.usc.edu/?id=1928&reference=ped" target="_blank" class="map">PED210. Subsequent classes meet in the Lyons Center Cardinal Room. Students MUST have ID.

CRS_DESC: a: Improvement in cardiorespiratory endurance, body composition, muscle endurance and flexibility; running, circuit training, resistance exercises; fitness principles and nutrition to develop individualized program.
a: Instruction and practice of basic strokes for beginners and intermediate swimmers; elementary springboard diving; water safety techniques; endurance training as a fitness program.
Fundamental instruction of surfing skills; water safety and wave etiquette; wave recognition and forecast interpretation; surf culture; board selection; surf related strengthening and conditioning.
Alternative ways to integrate sustainability practices into a daily routine; develop individual self-care modalities and connect to our planet; navigate climate anxiety.
Introduction to sleep as it relates to physical and mental performance; breathing and meditation modalities to support healthy sleep; study of sleep systems, disorders, strategies.
Introduction to the principles of mindfulness; application of learned techniques to enhance mind body awareness; cultivate strategies to improve physical and mental health.
Introduction to meditation, breathing techniques and postures as a means towards relaxation; increase muscle flexibility, understanding of basic anatomy and nutritional guidelines.
A continuing study of intermediate and advanced yoga postures, breathing techniques and meditation as a means toward relaxation and stress-reduction.

Ancient yoga practice combining postures, meditation, breathing, mantras and focus techniques; designed to improve mind body awareness, balance, strength, flexibility, techniques and nervous system function.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: First day meets in maps.usc.edu/?id=1928&reference=ped" target="_blank" class="map">PED210. Subsequent classes meet in either maps.usc.edu/?id=1928&reference=ped" target="_blank" class="map">PED201 or PED sub basement. Please email instructor for exaxct location.

CRS_DESC: Holistic discipline combining traditional yoga techniques with a modern medicine approach to treating a variety of health conditions; includes physical, mental and breathing practice.
Develop a strong fitness foundation through walking; fitness assessment and individualized programs; gait biomechanics and power walking; injury prevention; strategies for special populations.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Only first class meets in maps.usc.edu/?id=1928&reference=ped" target="_blank" class="map">PED210. Subsequent classes meet outside on stairs on the west side of PED building.

CRS_DESC: Teamwork building fitness course combining mindfulness and yoga with the dynamic movement of acrobatics; strength, balance and mind body awareness; stretching, spotting and counter balancing.

CRS_NAME: Principles of Yoga Through Community Outreach
CRS_DESC: Introduction and reinforcement of yoga postures, breathing techniques and meditation; sharing yoga principles and benefits with grade schools; teaching and community service opportunity.
Group fitness instruction incorporating a variety of training methods such as cycling, HITT (high intensity interval training), step, circuits; nutritional guidelines.
Introduction to distance running while training for a 5k, 10k or half marathon; gait biomechanics and running efficiency; injury prevention; nutrition guidelines.
Introduction to hiking; specific conditioning to develop muscle strength and endurance; equipment; various terrain, weather conditions, safety; environmental impact and trail etiquette.

Acquisition of backpacking knowledge and skills; conditioning plan; nutrition and equipment selection; ethics and environmental considerations; navigation, safety and wilderness first aid; trip planning.
Fundamental instruction of skills and tactics specific to sand volleyball and related physical conditioning; rules and strategies; history and culture.
a: Introduction to beginning and intermediate volleyball skills, rules, game tactics, and strategies. Emphasis on the development of: passing, setting, hitting, serving, blocking, and digging.
b: Advanced techniques; focus on offenses and defenses used in game situations.
Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginners and intermediate players; rules, scoring, court etiquette, strategies; singles and doubles; practice and match play.
Introduction to pickleball; develop basic skills, techniques and fundamentals; rules, scoring, etiquette and strategies of play (singles/doubles play).
Fundamental instruction of archery technique for beginners and intermediates; historical origins; form; the shot cycle; mindfulness; scoring; equipment; sport specific training.
Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginning and intermediate players; rules, scoring strategies; singles and doubles; practices and match play.
Reinforcement of basic strokes for experienced players; development of advanced strokes including serves, use of spin, counter hits, footwork; drills and match play.
Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginners and intermediate players; rules, scoring, strategies; footwork and court positioning; practical drills and games.
Fundamental instruction of skills and tactics specific to Futsal; rules; strategies; elements of play that differ from soccer; conditioning, drills and games.
Development of basic skills for beginners, intermediate and advanced players; rules, positioning elements of play, small group and team tactics; full field scrimmages.
Basic skills development and knowledge in stance, grip and swing mechanics; course strategy; use of woods, irons and putting; history rules and etiquette.
a: Basic skill development in dribbling, passing, shooting, rebounding and defense; rules, history, and etiquette; drills and full court games.
Instruction on the effects of stress as it relates to work, sport and academics; coping strategies are discussed and applied through physical conditioning interventions.
First aid safety education and infant, child, and adult CPR; demonstrated proficiency and successful completion of exam prepares students for Red Cross certification.

Introduction to coaching strategies; team management; philosophy; ethics; leadership. Methodologies in sport specific training; skill progression; conditioning; athlete motivation; budgeting; fundraising.

Skills and strategies of coaching principles promoting healthy lifestyle change. Motivational communication techniques; goal setting; designing safe, effective exercise program; health coach certification exam preparation.
Participation in the University's intercollegiate programs as sanctioned and governed by the PAC-10 conference and/or the NCAA. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: Central topics in the philosophy of economics, including models of economic rationality, the aggregation of preferences and the conditions in which markets yield undesirable outcomes.
Study of major philosophical theories of moral right and wrong, such as utilitarianism, Kantianism, egoism, virtue ethics, and theological ethics.
Philosophical content in representative European and American literature; philosophical problems about literature such as the nature of truth and meaning in fiction.
Intensive study of selected topics taken from Aristotle's writings in natural philosophy, in metaphysics, and in other areas of philosophy.
Development of philosophy in Great Britain from the seventeenth to the nineteenth centuries; emphasis on Locke, Berkeley, and Hume.
The rise of analytic philosophy; major ethical, metaphysical, epistemological, views; Frege, Moore, Russell, early and late Wittgenstein and Quine.
A systematic presentation of the main philosophical perspectives on the interactions between law and the social-political aspects of our lives.
Elements of propositional and quantified modal logic and the logic of counterfactual conditionals with an eye to some of their applications in contemporary philosophy.
Topics of current interest at the crossroads of philosophy of language, philosophy of mind and linguistics.
Examination of contemporary accounts of the nature, scope, sources--and value--of human knowledge and justified belief.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

First, second, and third laws; thermodynamic potentials, applications; distribution laws, kinetic theory, transport phenomena, specific heats.
b: Electromagnetic induction; AC circuits; Maxwell's equations.

a: Electrostatics, boundary value problems, multiple expansions, microscopic models of matter, magnetostatics. b: Maxwell's equations, potentials and gauge transformations; electromagnetic waves; wave guides; electromagnetic radiation; special relativity.

Training on available quantum computing hardware and the respective functional principles, available software, and algorithms; the opportunity to program quantum computers and run sample problems; hands-on tutorials.

Introduction to algorithm development. Integration of ordinary differential equations; chaotic systems; molecular dynamics; Monte Carlo integration and simulations; cellular automata and other complex systems. Recommended preparation: ability to program in C or C++
The theory of open quantum systems (i.e., systems coupled to an environment) with applications to chemistry, physics and quantum information processing.
a: General formulation of quantum mechanics with applications; theory of measurement; exactly solvable problems; angular momentum formalism.

CRS_DESC: Development of constitutional law by the courts; leading cases bearing on major constitutional issues; the federal system; powers of government; civil liberties.

CRS_NAME: Politics in the People's Republic of China
CRS_DESC: The Chinese revolution; social, political, and economic developments in post-1949 China; China after Mao Zedong (Mao Tse-tung).
Comparative analysis of the determinants of political violence, terrorism, and genocide and their social and moral consequences; application of theories to contemporary case studies.

Western political thought since the French Revolution. Rise of Marxist socialism, communism, anarchism, fascism, National Socialism, other doctrines; the democratic tradition; new theories of the state.
Thesis written under supervision, based on research begun in Honors I.

CRS_NAME: Directed Governmental and Political Leadership Internship
CRS_DESC: Intensive experience in governmental and political offices. Minimum time requirement; evaluation by office and intern report required.
Course covering substantive law, evidence, public speaking and use of societal mores in courtroom advocacy. Open only to Mock Trial team members.
Analysis of the political behavior and roles of ethnic and racial groups in the American political system; policy issues and patterns of political action are examined.
Analysis of the historic and contemporary roles of Latinos in the American political system; patterns of political participation and representation are examined.
Roles and behavior of major legal and political participants in the criminal justice system including the police, the legal profession, judges, and the public.

The political realities of selected environmental issues; resolving and implementing social priorities; interests, attitudes, strategies, and tactics of pressure groups; institutional biases and opportunities.
Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of American politics.

A comparative perspective on social and cultural forces that affect American laws and policies concerning discrimination on the basis of race or ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, age, and disability.
CRS_NOTE: • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_NAME: Civil and Political Rights and Liberties
CRS_DESC: An examination of debates and controversies surrounding the nature and scope of civil rights and civil liberties.
Psychological forces shaping politics and persons, processes and interactions; emphasis on political socialization and cognitive and effective orientations to politics.

CRS_NAME: Critical Issues in Law and Public Policy
CRS_DESC: Intensive examination of special topics in the field of law and public policy.
Modernization and political development in China and Japan; Asia's economic "miracles" (Taiwan, Japan, Korea, etc.); nationalism and communist movements in East and Southeast Asia.
How various developmental theories analyze the role of women as producers and how Third World women are increasing their role in development.
Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of comparative politics.
Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of political thought.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to psychological science, including historical and contemporary approaches. Behavior examined from biological, cognitive, social, developmental, and personality perspectives. Disorders and treatments.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: An integrative systems perspective of drugs; including their historical, economic, and cultural importance, psychopharmacology, addiction, relationship to crime, and therapeutic use in treating psychological disorders.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: An interdisciplinary approach to music, mind and brain. Explores music as an object with its own properties and as a form of human behavior.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_NAME: Scientific Inquiry and Reasoning in Health Care
CRS_DESC: Critical analysis and reasoning skills required to solve scientific problems in human behavior, including presentation of data, logic of research design, statistics, and research ethics. Not for major credit for Psychology majors.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the use of statistics in psychology: basic ideas in measurement; frequency distributions; descriptive statistics; concepts and procedures in statistical inference.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Supervised Research with department faculty.
Experimental and theoretical aspects of human memory, perception, thinking, and language. Lectures, demonstrations, and individual experiments. Prerequisite: 100g or departmental approval.
Receptor processes and stimulus organization; traditional topics in the perception of objects, space, time. Laboratory demonstrations and exercises.
Principles involved in classical and operant conditioning. Concentration on basic causes of behavior; consideration of the relevance of simple behavioral laws to complicated human behavior.
Experimental research methods in psychology; nature and concepts of scientific method.
Non-experimental research methods in psychology. Observational, survey and data analysis exercises
Neural bases of behavior. Concentration on sensory and motor processes and the interaction of neural, chemical, and hormonal systems.
Child and adolescent behavior and associated theories; exploration of the continuity between child and adult behavior. Laboratory projects.

Genetic, physical, and social influences during adult years on perception, learning and memory, intelligence, personality, social roles, and normal and deviant behavioral patterns. Laboratory demonstrations and exercises.
Exploration of ancient philosophical questions concerning the origins of human knowledge through empirical studies of infants, animals, and adults from diverse cultures.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Scientific perspective of close relationships: intimate relationships, friendships and others, evolutionary and biological bases of attraction and love, historical, social , cultural influences. Prerequisite: PSYC 100. (Duplicates credit in PSYC 359)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: PSYC 100
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Theoretical and experimental analysis of human behavior. Social processes involved in attitudes, conformity, compliance, interpersonal perception, liking, affiliation, aggression, altruism, and group dynamics.

The commonly diagnosed behavior pathologies; biological, social, cultural and developmental antecedents of abnormal behavior; principles of learning, perception and motivation, as they relate to psychopathology.

Introduction to the scientist-practitioner model of clinical psychology, including research methods, psychological assessment and diagnosis, psychotherapeutic interventions, and treatment of special populations.

Survey of current topics, technologies and techniques. Students acquire a basic understanding of how forensic psychologists contribute their unique expertise to the American legal system. Prerequisites: PSYC 100. Duplicates credit in former PSYC 465.
Psychological and physiological base of sexuality; gender identity, childbearing, birth control, venereal diseases; dysfunctions and treatments.

• Corequisite: PSYC 314

  • Note: The Psychology of Humor

CRS_DESC: Social, environmental, and physiological influences on behaviors associated with aggression, eating, reproduction, and sleep. Will focus on behavioral disorders such as addiction.

  • Note: It is highly recommended that students have taken any one of the courses listed in the Biological area in the Psychology Area Requirement: catalogue.usc.edu/preview_program.php?catoid=20&poid=28492&returnto=8371

CRS_DESC: An introductory overview of the primary historical issues, questions, concerns and developments that directly impact our current thought and action around disability and inclusion of disabled people in society.

Introduction to the major components of cognition (perception, memory, intelligence) in terms of the neural coding characteristic of the relevant brain areas.

Theory and research on cognitive processes in social behavior, to include social inference, cognition and emotion, the Self, social categorization, person memory, and attribution processes. Recommended preparation: PSYC-355.

Neuroscientific and psychological perspectives that investigate the basis of happiness and well-being.

A systematic study of the structure of Spanish. Topics include fundamental aspects of the sound system; word classes; sentences and their meaning; linguistic change and variation; standard and colloquial usage.

The language and culture of a particular area of study or profession, such as medicine and healthcare, political and social sciences, business and the law. Limited to 4 units for major or minor credit.

• Prerequisite: SPAN 260 and SPAN 261
  • Note: Section 62210 focuses in the fields of Business and the Law. Students will engage in service learning projects in both sections. Section 62225 focuses on Spanish used in the fields of journalism and social media.

Lecture and laboratory in computer animation: geometric modeling, motion specification, lighting, texture mapping, rendering, compositing, production techniques, systems for computer-synthesized animation using Maya software.
The fundamentals of lighting and rendering in real-time. Creating complex, compelling and dynamic scenes and manipulating them in real-time using Unreal Engine.
The basics of character design for animation: anatomy, poses, facial expressions, silhouettes, and anthropomorphism. Development of a portfolio.

Survey of contemporary concepts and approaches to production in the current state of film and video effects work. Digital and traditional methodologies will be covered, with a concentration on digital exercises illustrating modern techniques.
All aspects of digital effects animation, including particles, dynamics, and fluids. Creating water, fire, explosions, and destruction in film.
Advanced techniques for animating 3-D creature characters in games. An emphasis on unique non-human fantasy characters.
Creating visual music animation in a variety of forms and styles. Exploring the relationship between music, movement, and visual expression. Freshmen and sophomores not eligible.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration closed to the following class level(s): Freshmen, Sophomore

CRS_DESC: Individual research under faculty guidance.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts

CRS_DESC: Introduction to software packages and practices exploring current animation techniques that leverage simulation systems. Artificial intelligence as a tool for animation.
Focus on film grammar, perspective, and layout, staging and acting as it relates to storyboarding for animation.

CRS_NAME: Live Action Integration with Visual Effects
CRS_DESC: Survey of the digital techniques required to successfully marry live action shooting with CGI elements and green screen footage.
Create 3D models for environments for urban and natural settings and props including vehicles, rocks, trees and furniture.
A creative development workshop for animated pitch storytelling, supported by an introduction to character development and story structure fundamentals.
The practical aspects of producing a 2-D animation series. Identifying and understanding the 2-D pipeline.
Applying traditional principles to 3-D character animation in Maya, with a focus on character performance and acting.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTAN 530 and CTAN 533
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Production of an animation project from creative concept and design through completion.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTAN 519
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Fundamental principles of motion capture technology explored while working through a structured series of assignments based around performance, gesture and motion.
A creative 3-D motion graphics course focusing on animation technique, design and skills in Cinema 4-D.
Techniques and cinematic language employed in both live action and animation by cinematographers and layout artists to tell visual stories.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTAN 586
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Research, development, and preparation of the concept, script, storyboards and preliminary designs for thesis projects to be executed in CTAN 594abz.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Individual exploration in the areas of contemporary technology, animation techniques or experimental film through internships, residencies or directed studies. Open only to Animation and Digital Arts master students.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_NAME: Visions of Diversity in the Cinematic Arts
CRS_DESC: Representations of marginalized groups in digital media, and how they have shaped conversations, altered public discourse and policy, and impacted the lives of underrepresented people.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Gateway to majors and minors in cinematic arts. Technique, aesthetics, criticism, and social implications of cinema. Lectures accompanied by screenings of appropriate films.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Exploration of the economic, technological, aesthetic, and ideological characteristics of the televisual medium; study of historical development of television and video including analysis of key works; introduction to TV/Video theory and criticism.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_NAME: Race, Class, and Gender in American Film
CRS_DESC: Analyzes issues of race, class and gender in contemporary American culture as represented in the cinema.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_NAME: History of the International Cinema II
CRS_DESC: The development of international cinema from World War II to the present. Lectures, screenings and discussions.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Theories of Cinema and Media
CRS_DESC: Introduction to theoretical works in cinema and media studies, emphasizing concepts to interrogate media objects. Lectures and discussion orient majors to their cohort and field.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinema and Media Studies

CRS_NAME: Nationalism and Postcolonialism in Southeast Asian Cinema
CRS_DESC: Cinema from Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam in local and global cultural contexts.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the COLT department but may qualify for major credit in CTCS. To register, enroll in COLT 379.

CRS_DESC: The development of American cinema since the end of Classical Hollywood and its relationship to American history and culture. Lectures, screenings and discussions.
Exercise in writing film and television criticism using new and classic films and television programs.

CRS_NAME: Studies in National and Regional Media
CRS_DESC: Detailed investigation of traditions, achievements, and trends of film and/or electronic media in a particular country or region.
Intensive survey of African American cinema; topics include history, criticism, politics, and cinema's relationship to other artifacts of African American culture.
Detailed examination of film/television from the perspectives and insights of Cultural Studies; focus on the production and reception of cultural texts, practices, and communities.
Examines how gender and sexuality are figured in cinema and television with an emphasis on the development of feminist media theory.
Rigorous examination of film and/or television genres: history, aesthetics, cultural context, social significance, and critical methodologies.
Lectures and readings on creative problems in the motion picture industry; current films; interviews with visiting producers, directors, writers, performers.
Lectures and readings on creative problems in the television industry; study of current and historical trends, interviews with producers, directors, writers and performers.
Intensive topical study of the social, political and economic contexts in which media are produced, distributed and monetized.
Intensive study of the style of an auteur, studio, film or television making mode in terms of thematic and formal properties and their influences upon the art of film.
Influential ideas and theoretical approaches that have shaped the making and study of film. Students are encouraged to take this course in their junior year.
Historical survey of global cinema from its beginnings until 1945.

CRS_NAME: Survey History of the United States Sound Film
CRS_DESC: Survey history of the United States film from 1927 to the present, with emphasis upon film as art form, economic institution, technology, and cultural product.
A survey course exploring the historical, cultural, business, creative, and technological aspects of the new interactive media.
Seminar on media's impact in defining nation and/or region in specific cultural contexts. Also addresses issues of exile, diaspora, transnationalism and globalism.
Introduction to central concepts, key theories and leading figures in cultural studies, particularly as they relate to issues of popular culture and visual media.
Aesthetic, historical and ideological issues in avant-garde film and video.

CRS_NAME: Seminar in Film and Television Authors
CRS_DESC: Seminar in the style of an auteur, studio, filmmaking, or televisual mode in terms of thematic and formal properties and their influences upon the art of film and/or television.
Contemporary theoretical frameworks and their relationship to film and television studies. Topics differ from semester to semester.
Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTCS 794D
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Processes used in the themed entertainment industry to research concepts, develop concepts and deliver creative product.
Covers core skills for creating in a digital game engine, the role of prototyping in the game development and the use of version control systems.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (CTIN 101 or ITP 165)
  • Concurrent enrollment: CTIN 290

CRS_DESC: Exploration of a variety of moving image aesthetics and methodologies in order to highlight how the language of cinema shapes contemporary digital and interactive media practices.
Hands-on creating experiences for students who want to work as crew on an advanced game project.
An introduction to building for themed entertainment and the experience of live operating a ride or exhibit.

CRS_NAME: Fundamentals of User Research and Experience
CRS_DESC: An introduction to games user research, interface design and user experience, covering both theory and practice.
Production and project management of video games from concept to release and beyond.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: ITP 180
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the ITP department but may qualify for major credit in CTIN. To register, enroll in ITP 393.

CRS_DESC: Workshop on the production of miniature golf holes, considering theming, experience, and build.
The scope of visual game design, including the role of characters, architecture, indoor and outdoor space, and environmental effects and sounds. Recommended preparation: CTAN 443
Concepts and methods of usability assessment. The emphasis will be on understanding the issues surrounding game interfaces, and utilizing usability assessment methods.
Introduction to the techniques, terminology, and implementation of sounds in games, including establishing a sense of place and concepts of realistic sound.
An overview of tabletop roleplaying games and the design space around roleplaying.
Overview of current business models in games and interactive media, methods for pitching and getting products funded; copyright and intellectual property.
Examine two game products from concept to delivery; introduce students to each of the professional disciplines involved in making digital games. Recommended preparation: CTIN 488.
Rigorous examination of interactive entertainment: genres, history, aesthetics, cultural context, and social significance. Topics vary by semester.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: In this class we study video games, cultural theory, and other media as we ask questions about the persistence of dystopian narratives in print and visual culture.

CRS_DESC: An advanced dive into the structure of the games industry with a focus on emerging trends and the future of games as business and entertainment.
A workshop on focused design tasks, creating many levels on paper and in game engines.

CRS_NAME: Directing for Games and Interactive Media
CRS_DESC: An introduction to the skills of directorial perspective, scene breakdown, thematic intent, project planning, team building, communication, situational decision-making and response to change.
Design of game projects using immersive input devices. Development of play mechanics, feedback systems and game design for immersive environments.
An introduction to making games. Students will explore the principles of game design through the entirely analog creation of card, board and tabletop games.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: A follow-up to the introductory game design class, this course will introduce more advanced concepts in game design and game theories, including ideation, digital prototyping and level design.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
Students work in teams to polish and finalize a functional digital game suitable for distribution via the web and/or submission into independent games festivals.
Production and building for themed attractions. Large scale multidisciplinary teams work together to produce themed entertainment experiences.
Pitching, production planning, forming a company and seeking funding for your creative media idea. Duplicates credit in former CTIN 497ab.
Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema, television, and/or interactive media; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

Overview of foundational concepts required for design, development and evaluation of interactive entertainment and transmedia-based interventions at the intersection of neuroscience, public health and medicine. Recommended preparation: Proficiency in conducting literature reviews; social media use; using interactive media and playing games. Open only to seniors and graduate students.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior, Senior (fifth year), Master Student, Professional Year 1, Doctoral Student, Graduate Visitor

CRS_NAME: Research Methods for Innovation, Engagement and Assessment
CRS_DESC: Planning, designing, and analyzing a research study for a digital media project. Production of a written report and presentation. Recommended preparation: CTIN-506, CTIN-541, and CTCS-505.
Capstone course for assigned Game Directors or Area Leads to create an innovative, large-scale game project.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTIN 529A
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Game Design and Development
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: The development of interactive experiences with an emphasis on prototyping and development.
Rapid prototyping and forward iteration of thesis project ideas developed in CTIN 548.
Experimental studio course in application of technology to interactive experience. Open to Interactive Media MFA students only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTIN 534
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Interactive Media

CRS_DESC: An advanced production workshop in which students design and prepare for the production of their advanced project. Open to Interactive Media MFA students only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTIN 532
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Interactive Media

CRS_DESC: The fundamentals of 3-D real time game engines, scripting for interactivity, and building games with digital tools.
Research project leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_NAME: Crew for Graduate Advanced Game Project
CRS_DESC: Students from many disciplines work in large teams to create an innovative, large-scale interactive media or game project.
Small student teams produce, playtest and polish high quality games and experiences in an intensive project based studio setting.
A project that showcases integrative mastery of prior and newly acquired knowledge, skills and interests. Permission of instructor required.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTIN 503
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts (Media Arts, Games and Health), Computer Science (Games), Interactive Media (Games and Health), Computer Science Games

CRS_DESC: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC. Open to M.F.A., Interactive Media majors only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTIN 594a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Interactive Media

CRS_DESC: Introduces contemporary concepts of production, emphasizing the variety of contemporary media and significant related concepts. Projects created using laptops, phones and networks.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_NAME: Originating and Developing Ideas for Film
CRS_DESC: Exercises in observation, imaginative association, visualization, etc., that deepen the creative process, leading to ideas, stories, characters, and images for narrative, documentary, and experimental films.
Introduction to the interrelationship of visuals, sound, and editing in cinematic communication. Workshops in directing and producing. Individual and group projects.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_NAME: Directing in Documentary, Fiction and New Media
CRS_DESC: Basic concepts of directing in new media, documentary and fictional narrative. Includes work with actors, documentary concepts, and creation of short new media projects.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Concurrent enrollment: CTPR 295

CRS_DESC: The aesthetics and tools of the major disciplines of cinematic arts: producing, cinematography, sound, and editing.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Concurrent enrollment: CTPR 294

CRS_DESC: Principles of visual and aural communication; idea development and realization using image, movement, pace, the spoken word and other sounds; small crew projects.
Use of high definition motion picture equipment to explore the fundamentals of shot design, movement and lighting. In class group projects.
Theory, techniques, and practices in picture editing; use of standard editing equipment; individual projects.

CRS_NAME: Creating the Motion Picture Sound Track
CRS_DESC: Techniques and aesthetics for recording production sound, editing dialogue, sound effects, music, Foley and preparing for the mix. For film, television, and other media.
Preparation of director's preproduction blockout; study of direction for live, tape, and film production, for both dramatic and informational television.
Basic procedures and techniques applicable to production of all types of films; demonstration by production of a short film from conception to completion.
Analysis of a single film or television project from conception through release to understand the balance between creativity and business in making filmed content.
The practice of video podcast production and the skills to develop, produce, record and post original episodes. Podcast formats vary by semester.

CRS_NAME: Visual Structure for Interactive Games and Animation
CRS_DESC: Controlling the relationship between story and visual structures for interactive games and traditional or computer-generated animation.
The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.
An exploration of the worldwide media and content business and the roles and careers of the people who develop and monetize creative ideas and storytelling.
Workshop in how editing can shape storytelling, using content from a variety of media and in various styles. Modern non-linear equipment and techniques.
Lecture-laboratory in makeup relating it to mood of the story and emulsion of the camera stock.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Special Effects in Cinema
CRS_DESC: Introductory workshop in the aesthetics and practices of special effects, embracing both the classical and contemporary modes.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: CTPR 423 requires a mandatory safety seminar. Contact the SCA Student Production Office at (213) 740-2895 for date and place.

CRS_DESC: Camera and lighting workshop in color cinematography, beginning with digital still photography and moving into 16mm and advanced digital cameras. In-class exercises.
Theory, discussion, and practical application of production planning during preproduction and production of a film.
To provide students with basic working knowledge of both the skills of the motion picture set and production operations through classroom lectures and hands-on experience.
Exploration of the various aspects of color grading and how it can enhance storytelling.
The tools and skills necessary to turn an idea into a documentary story, using sample reels, pitches, and writing to develop a professional proposal.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: CTPR 431 requires a mandatory safety seminar. Contact the SCA Student Production Office at (213) 740-2895 for date and place.

CRS_DESC: A comprehensive overview of the role of the producer. How projects are conceived, developed, packaged, financed and marketed.
Aesthetic and technical skills of production and post-production sound necessary to create a motion picture soundtrack.
Integrating visual and scenario design in the construction of worlds as containers for narrative in documentary, drama, fiction, fantasy, and immersive media.
Assistant crew experience on a capstone project including specified weekends. Overview of roles and fundamental thinking typical of each craft.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 310
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Intensive examination of skills and techniques necessary for successful performances in film and television. Practical application through in-class exercises and assigned projects.
Introduction to drafting, set design, set decoration and creating models for students with diverse abilities. Guest lectures, group discussions and hands-on workshop.

Analysis of the unique structures in the entertainment industry for organizing and managing creativity. Students research and chart pathways to leadership. Open only to juniors, seniors, and graduate students.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Senior (fifth year), Master Student
  • Note: Section 18562 Designed for Production students in directing, writing, or producing. Preparing for a freelance life, finding representation, building networks, pitching yourself and understanding the business side of a creative career.

CRS_DESC: Financing, budgeting, management as applied to films; problems of distribution, including merchandising, cataloging, evaluation, and film library management.

CRS_DESC: Concepts and skills in directing sketch comedy shows, using the techniques of live television. Hands-on experience on live weekly shows. Recommended preparation: CTPR 371, or CTPR 476, or CTPR 484, or CTPR 523, or CTPR 532.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Includes additional required attendance for Friday Show Dates on 2/28, 4/4, 4/25 from 3 PM-9 PM.

CRS_DESC: Practical instruction in script breakdown, location surveys, traditional and computer-aided working drawings, model making, set decoration, construction and scenic departments.
Presenting ideas for feature and television projects to buyers: shaping ideas for pitching, assessing and targeting the marketplace, in-class pitching of projects.

CRS_NAME: Practicum in On-Screen Direction of Actors
CRS_DESC: Concentration on the basic skills in working with actors from a director's point of view.
A real world approach to spotting music for film: why film music exists and the many ways it is used in storytelling. For filmmakers as well as composers.
Pairs produce, direct, shoot, and edit a short documentary on a subject of their choice. Finished projects will be suitable for broadcast/festivals.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: CTPR 474 requires a mandatory safety seminar. Contact the SCA Student Production Office at (213) 740-2895 for date and place.

CRS_DESC: Directing comedy: casting, rehearsing, directing actors, scene analysis, staging, shooting, and editing, leading to the filming of a two-person comic scene
Concepts of directing for motion pictures, emphasizing the working relationship of actors and directors. Scenes will be staged in class and filmed for class presentation.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 310
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Directors, producers, cinematographers, editors and sound designers collaborate to produce, shoot, edit and deliver fictional, documentary or experimental projects.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 450
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab.

CRS_DESC: Collaborative production and postproduction of an original episodic drama, shot on original sets on stage and on location.
Translating traditional storytelling tools into short form comedy that stands out online. Writing, directing and producing creative projects designed for current online platforms.
Writing, budgeting, shooting, editing and directing a music video and commercial. Getting the job, dealing with the band, working with the record and advertising companies.
Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema and/or television; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.
Foundations for fruitful collaborative experiences via readings, presentations, in-class exercises and real-life challenges and advice from professionals.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: The Friday class session is for the Graduate Equity and Inclusion Lab, which will meet twice during the semester, on February 17 and March 10.

CRS_DESC: Exploring the relationship between story structure and visual structure, discussion of aesthetics and technical controls, in-class examples and screenings, photographic assignments.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (CTAN 547 or CTIN 534 or CTPR 504 or CTPR 507)

CRS_DESC: The effective communication of ideas through the language of cinema. Individual and small group exercises; introductions to producing, directing, editing, cinematography and sound.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Practicum in group production, emphasizing the collaborative process and the expressive use of sound and image.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 507 and CTWR 505
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the software necessary to create previs, pitchvis, CG films and quick experiments to practice creativity without being on set.
A comprehensive overview of the world of reality television; each student will develop and pitch an original reality-based program.
How to direct comedy or dramatic scenes, using multiple camera techniques. Students also serve as crew members, learning lighting, mixing, studio controls, and stage management.
Collaboration on projects using motion-tracking technology to raise the CG production value and realize the vision of previously produced animatics.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (CTPR 514 or CTAN 454 or CTAN 564 or CTIN 534)

CRS_DESC: A preproduction workshop for the research and planning of a documentary project to be executed in CTPR 547 or an advanced production workshop class. Prerequisite: CTPR 508.
Practical experience in staging dramatic narrative scenes, emphasizing directing actors, rehearsal techniques and camera blocking.
Practicum in more complex directing issues concentrating both on performance and exploration of shaping scenes visually through blocking of action and placement of camera.
Editorial construction of sequences to analyze the interrelationships of the various film elements, both visual and aural.
Close study through practical in class exercises of the technical and aesthetic principles of cinematography. Introduction to 16mm film and advanced digital cameras.

• Prerequisite: 1 from (CTPR 508 or CTAN 547)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Definition, examination and practical experience in the role of the line producer as it relates to preproduction, production and post production.

An intensive workshop experience in which students, crewing in their area of specialization, complete the shooting and postproduction of projects up to 12 minutes in length. Qualifying courses: for directors, CTPR 532, and for cinematographers, CTPR 537;
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 508
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Intensive workshop; students shoot and finish documentary projects up to about 25 minutes. Qualifying courses: for directors, CTPR 431 or CTPR 531; for cinematographers, CTPR 424 or CTPR 537.

• Prerequisite: 1 from (CTPR 450 or CTPR 508)
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Telling cinematic stories using visual effects and virtual backgrounds, environments, and characters. Hands-on exercises emphasizing directing. Prerequisite: CTAN 462. Recommended preparation: CTAN 555 or CTPR 532 or CTPR 537. Open only to Cinematic Arts students.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTAN 462
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: An advanced production class in directing. Encounters with experienced directors; and individual student production of a short. Recommended preparation: CTPR 533.

• Prerequisite: CTPR 532
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Study of the technical and aesthetic elements of sound design at the professional level. Intended for those contemplating a career in the field of audio. Prerequisite: CTPR 540 or CTPR 546 or CTPR 547.

CRS_NAME: Production Design in Film, TV, Commercials and Games
CRS_DESC: In-depth analysis and fully detailed breakdown of a script or idea for story, character, sets, locations, set dressing, props, fabrics, color and texture.

CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (CTPR 421 or CTPR 535 or CTPR 480 or CTPR 484 or CTPR 486 or CTPR 546 or CTPR 547)

CRS_DESC: Advanced camera and lighting techniques for those considering a professional career in cinematography.

• Prerequisite: 1 from (CTPR 424 or CTPR 537)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Developing, pitching and selling your feature motion picture and TV projects.

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Takes projects from conception to sale, including development, production, post-production, and marketing. Students will develop original projects.
