  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Writing a feature-length screenplay based on treatment developed in CTWR 206a. Includes a first draft and a polish.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 206a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television

CRS_DESC: Examination of the fundamental elements of a good story, and how to use those elements to develop new screenplay ideas. Recommended preparation: CTWR 106b.
Detailed investigation of source material and how it translates to screen. Special attention paid to character, genre and story as relates to intellectual property.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: The fundamentals of writing for dramatic episodic television. Writing scenes from popular television shows and examination of television story structure.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (CTWR 100 or CTWR 402 or CTWR 409 or CTWR 413)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (CTWR 100 or CTWR 402 or CTWR 409 or CTWR 413)
  • Note: Sections 19353, 19362, 19364 are restricted to WST majors.

CRS_DESC: The fundamentals of writing for comedic episodic television. Writing scenes from popular comedy series and examination of half-hour television comedy story structure.
Development of an original narrative podcast. Emphasis on dramatic elements of auditory storytelling and character development.
Introduction to writing compelling scenes, creating authentic characters, three-act structure and feature film outlining.

CRS_NAME: Character Development and Storytelling for Games
CRS_DESC: An exploration of characters and story worlds as they relate to gaming with an emphasis on emotionally rich environments in interactive entertainment. Recommended preparation: CTIN 488
In-depth analysis of the craft of writing prime-time episodic television. Examination of situation comedies and dramas through weekly screenings and lectures.
Preparation of scripts for short films: form, structure, planning. Open only to Cinematic Arts Film and Television Production majors.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Students study story structure and develop several story outlines, write a short script for possible production, a feature film outline and first act. Recommended preparation: CTWR-416. Open only to Cinematic Arts Film and Television Production majors.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 413
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production, Cinema-Television

CRS_DESC: Principles of the feature film; creating theme, character and structure that combine into a feature-length story treatment.
Creation of script with extensive workshopping of scenes in class leading to a first draft and revision as a final assignment.
Critical analysis of story structure from classic films to contemporary works. Identification of key story concepts and elements of three-act structure. 2.0, not repeatable.
Evaluation of completed scripts prior to their production. Coverage and analysis of scripts as potential properties from the perspective of a production company.

b: Completion and revision of Senior Thesis project and introduction to motion picture industry procedures and practices through interaction with industry representatives. Open to B.F.A. Writing for Screen and Television students only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 418A
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television

CRS_DESC: Revision of original pilot script, writing of mid-season episode, and completion of bible for original dramatic series developed in first semester.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 419a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television

CRS_DESC: Examination and creation of the world, characters, and concept for an original hour-long dramatic series. Writing an outline for an original dramatic pilot.
Detailed investigation of a specific screenwriter's style and the works they've influenced. Lectures include screenings and visiting screenwriters.
Detailed investigation of various television writers' styles, the worlds they have created, and the works they've influenced. Lectures include screenings and visiting television writers.
Writing an episode of an existing half-hour comedy series, with emphasis on the anatomy of a joke, comedic structure and character.

CRS_NAME: Writing for Film and Television Genres
CRS_DESC: Preparation of proposals and scripts for different types of film or television programming: emphasis on conception, structure, characterization and format.

CRS_NAME: Writing the Original Situation Comedy Pilot
CRS_DESC: Advanced workshop for writing an original half-hour comedy series, including a pilot script, summary of characters, and story lines for first season.

CRS_NAME: Writing the Original Dramatic Series Pilot
CRS_DESC: An advanced workshop in which students create an original dramatic series, including a first script and a summary of characters and story lines. Prerequisite: CTWR-421 or CTWR-434.

CRS_NAME: Rewriting the Original Dramatic Series Pilot
CRS_DESC: An advanced workshop in which an original hour-long television pilot will be rewritten with emphasis on character, world creation and future story lines. Prerequisite(s): CTWR 439. Recommended preparation: CTWR 411.
An advanced workshop in which a feature length screenplay will be rewritten using a specific methodology that focuses on a macro to micro approach to revision.

CRS_NAME: Pitching for Film, Television and New Media
CRS_DESC: Emphasis of verbal storytelling and presentation skills in motion pictures, television and new media with concentration on story and character.
Examination and analysis of various topics, issues, and resources pertaining to creative, legal, and business perspectives for writers in the entertainment industry.

CRS_NAME: Staff Writing the Sketch Comedy Show
CRS_DESC: Staff writing a sketch comedy show with emphasis on creating comedic characters, political humor, monologue writing, and joke construction. A live show will be produced. Prerequisite: CTWR 404
Strengthening and deepening the ability to conceive and develop ideas that will lead to compelling, authentic, and personally meaningful films. Duplicates credit in CTWR 528.
Introduction to the fundamentals of storytelling with techniques and practices that work best for animated stories.

Dramaturgy for the fiction and nonfiction work. Techniques for creating the original or adapted theatrical length script. b: Development of an outline and feature length, original script. Open to graduate screenwriting (CNTV) and dramatic writing (Theatre) students only.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television, Theatre (Dramatic Writing)

CRS_DESC: Comprehensive re-writing of second and third drafts of a feature screenplay leading to a polished and professional piece.

Critical analysis of the structure of films from the classics to current award winners. Students will learn how to identify key story concepts and break down three act structure in finished films and scripts.

Part B -- writing the series bible and mid-season episode -- is part two of the television thesis course. Students develop their original series further by writing the bible for the series and the mid-season episode which is reflective of storylines, characters and settings developed in part A of the course. Open to M.F.A. Writing for Screen and Television students only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 519A
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television

CRS_DESC: Intensive workshop oriented specifically to writing and rewriting the most effective and telling dramatic scenes to heighten audience participation and greater story impact.
Investigation of development process for hour-long television, addressing issues of character, world, story and concept. Vetting of multiple series ideas for viability.

Introduction to formal elements of the screenplay through lectures and the workshopping of a complete first draft of a feature-length script. Prerequisite: CTAN 536 or CTWR 505 or CTWR 518. Recommended preparation: CTWR 516.
Emphasizes structural elements crucial to the feature film. Techniques for creating an original or adapted theatrical-length script.
Rewriting the feature-length screenplay. Focus on macro to micro approach to revision.

Development of an original half-hour comedy series; writing of the pilot episode and series bible. Prerequisite: CTWR 514a. Open only to master students in Theatre (Dramatic Writing) and Writing for Screen and Television.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 514a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Theatre (Dramatic Writing), Writing for Screen and Television
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Development of an original one hour drama series; writing of the pilot episode and series bible. Prerequisite: CTWR 514a. Open only to master students in Theatre (Dramatic Writing) and Writing for Screen and Television.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 514a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Theatre (Dramatic Writing), Writing for Screen and Television
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Examination of the links between the brain, creativity, neuroscience and storytelling. Through lectures, screenings, and readings, students will log dreams for use in creative exercises.
Advanced feature screenwriting, emphasizing the rewrite of a first draft script.
Development and pitching of ideas for motion pictures, episodic and television pilots. Reducing ideas to basic components enhancing verbal presentation skills.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (CTWR 305 or CTWR 415B or CTWR 514B or CTWR 533)

CRS_DESC: An in-depth investigation of the close interrelationships among technology, culture and communication to form a solid foundation for digital authoring. Duplicates credit in former IML 101.

CRS_NAME: Media Arts and Practice Studio II
CRS_DESC: Intermediate laboratory exploring computational systems through a series of critical design prompts. Emphasis on digital representation, time-based processes, abstract data and the relationship between humans and computers.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: IML 202
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Media Arts and Practice

CRS_DESC: An introduction to the principles of visual and graphic design within the field of media art.
An introduction to the design of poetic and creative artworks using foundational programming concepts.

CRS_NAME: Race, Class and Gender in Digital Culture
CRS_DESC: Critical analysis of the categories of race, class and gender within the diverse digital spaces of contemporary culture, from video games to the digital divide.
CRS_NOTE: • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_DESC: An introduction to the fundamentals of creative web coding and design, with best practices and new creative directions.
Development of documentation and archival strategies, with an emphasis on techniques of personal and professional representation.
An introduction to audio and sound technologies, focusing on creating artwork using sound as a primary modality.
An introduction to digital storytelling with a focus on cameras, sound recording and editing techniques to create short, professional video projects.
Emphasizing rigorous multimedia research and authorship strategies, this course prepares students to undertake large-scale digital projects.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (IML 104 or IML 201)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: An introduction to 3-D modeling, with an emphasis on the fundamentals of texturing and lighting for use in animation, game art and interactive 3-D spaces.
Exploration of extended human computer interaction, including new forms of haptic, sonic and other sense modalities, through physical computing and spatial interfaces.
Designing media experiences that move beyond vision and sound by incorporating elements of smell, taste, touch and/or other sensory systems.
Developing audio and video remix projects with source material from existing media archives and collections.
Traditions and emerging practices in multimedia storytelling. Narrative convergences of literature, film, television, comics, mixed reality, videogames or physical/virtual environments.
Exploration of spatial sound practices, focusing on sound installation art, sonic visualization and audio storytelling techniques.
Exploration of advanced techniques in digital audio and video storytelling in the field of media art.
Production of a digital thesis project.
Designing fictional stories, images and worlds to imagine possible futures as a form of speculative design and critical inquiry.
Investigation of the impact of natural patterns on digital media design. Explores the relationships among chaos, harmony, beauty, proportion, spirituality, holistic systems and shaped experience.
A hands-on mentored research lab experience within the context of media art and in association with a real-world project.
Exploration of advanced techniques for the creation of mixed reality artworks combining digital content and physical environments.
Individual research and readings.
Selected topics in multimedia literacy.

CRS_NAME: The Praxis of Sonic and Visual Media
CRS_DESC: An introduction to digital authorship at the graduate level, with a focus on the potential of multimedia scholarship and networked dissemination.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student, Professional Year 1

CRS_DESC: An introduction to video in academic scholarship. Acquisition and editing of images and sound through a series of short, non-fiction media projects.
A hands-on mentored graduate research lab experience within the context of media art and in association with a real-world project.
Research leading to the masters degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_NAME: Media Arts and Practice Colloquium/Professional Seminar
CRS_DESC: Orientation to the profession, opportunities, presentation and analysis of recent developments and applications in Media Arts and Practice. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former CNTV 603)
Introduction to contemporary media theory, with attention to posthumanism, networks, and the post-cinematic, and a demonstration of these concepts in media art.
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794a)
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794b)
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794c)
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794d)
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794z)

CRS_NAME: Audio Design for Animation and Immersive Media
CRS_DESC: Experimental and traditional audio design practices for animation, culminating in an immersive audio project utilizing acoustic design, surround sound and professional recording and editing tools.
Principles of 2-D and 3-D digital animation and AI applied to scientific themes and research topics.
Explores the relationship of science, philosophy and art to new forms of animation practice, including Artificial Intelligence with a focus on dreams and consciousness.

CRS_NAME: Writing and Story Art for Vision and Motion
CRS_DESC: Story, narrative structure and storyboarding techniques examined through a creative lens.
Creating a one-minute animated film, installation, VR performance or new media project with sound, including development, pre-production, production and post-production.
Incorporating classic stop motion techniques for puppet performance and animation. Emphasis on timing, performance, movement, animation and gesture.

CRS_NAME: Theory and Practice in Contemporary Animation
CRS_DESC: Seminar and practicum featuring an inclusive investigation of contemporary animation theory and practices, with an emphasis on non-mainstream and marginalized themes, voices and methodology.
The history and practice of media-based installation art, from site-specific architectural projection mapping, to activist and public art, video sculptures and immersive, physical transformations.

CRS_NAME: Animation for Virtual Characters, Robotics and AI
CRS_DESC: Designed to explore the illusion of life, sentience and how to develop compelling animation, diverse stories and gesture for virtual characters, AI and robotics.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Research and development of the thesis project in expanded animation. Presentation of the thesis proposal at the end of the semester.
A special projects course in which students study and create new works with a visiting master artist, animator, or researcher.
Credit on acceptance of Thesis.

CRS_NAME: Navigating Media and News in the Digital Age
CRS_DESC: Students will be engaged as discriminating media/news consumers and contributors. Emphasis on critical skills needed to understand, employ, enjoy and help shape our media landscape.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_NAME: Contours of Change in Media and Communication
CRS_DESC: Provides an introduction to cultivating a curious, critical, and proactive approach to the challenges of social change. Students will be encouraged to develop an expansive and critical definition and understanding of change as it relates to the role of media and communication in producing and responding to political and cultural transformations that shape our status as citizens and our ideas of citizenship.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one disc

CRS_DESC: Collaborative, cutting-edge, experimental, experiential, interdisciplinary, results-based classes taught in new ways and places. Recommended preparation: ASCJ-220.

Production and distribution of information within large organizations; information networks, organization structure, control and decision-making functions. Resources necessary for effective organizational communication systems.
Theories, core concepts and practice in management of communication; analysis based on cases, structured and semi-structured data, historical research and participant observation.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication Management

CRS_DESC: Roles, responsibilities and requirements of communication functions within organizations; design and implementation of communication plans; strategic messaging for internal and external audiences.
How work settings impact communication: social structures of communication, organizational culture, socialization, feedback, dissent and adaptation. Applications for all working professionals.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication Management

CRS_DESC: Examines images and image manipulation in communication, management and social control. Synthesizes work ranging from cognition and interpersonal behavior to mass media and popular culture.

Conceptual frameworks for analyses and visualization of information and data. Principles and strategies for data transformation, intermediate statistical analyses, data-based presentation, sense-making.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Applied Communication Research, Communication Data Science, Communication Data Science, Communication Management

CRS_DESC: Theory and research on persuasion, value and attitude formation and change; implication for communication and behavior in various market and professional contexts.

CRS_NAME: Communication Ethics for New Media and Technology
CRS_DESC: Ethics for new media and technology. Leverages case studies, historical analysis, observational analysis. Equips data-oriented communication practitioners to be ethical stewards of data.
Measurement and advanced data gathering and statistical analyses; data mining; data model formulation for prediction. Statistical inferences for and effective communication about solutions.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CMGT 540
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication Management

CRS_NAME: Communication in the Luxury Fashion Industry
CRS_DESC: Examines luxury fashion marketing communication, focusing on connecting with the audience. Topics include history of the industry, media channels, digital platforms and communicating values.
Covers various segments of beauty, personal care and wellness brands and how they utilize communication strategies to differentiate products and persuade targeted consumers.
Impact of television, satellites, computers, and other new technologies; competing theories about the role of technology in society; historical effects of introducing new technologies.

CRS_NAME: The Industry, Science and Culture of Video Games
CRS_DESC: History, social dynamics, and cultural impact of video games; developments in technology and design; issues confronting the video game industry and organizations.
Data collection and elementary statistical analysis in communication management. Methods include surveys, focus groups, content analysis, experiments, secondary data sources.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication Management, Communication Management

CRS_DESC: Communication strategies for product marketing and advertising; communication's role in developing domestic and international marketplaces; practical applications of persuasion theory.
Explores how organizations combine values, culture, experience and markets to create meaning, engage audience and customers, and grow.
History and evolution of sports media industry; traditional, new and alternative sports media; globalization of sports; sports promotions and personalities.

CRS_NAME: Hollywood 3.0-Entertainment Industry in the Convergence Age
CRS_DESC: In-depth analysis of the challenges confronting the entertainment industry in the wake of media convergence including a survey of media convergence history and theories.

Understanding dynamics in entertainment markets enabled by emerging digital technologies; broad and niche strategies to target appropriate audiences, building audience engagement with entertainment content identities.
Focuses on management, production and distribution of scripted film, television and web stories to understand visual storytelling as a communicative strategy for advertising and education.
Foundational and advanced practices for copywriting and related design incommunication; integrated analysis of concepts and pragmatics surrounding creativity forcommunication effectiveness

CRS_NAME: Online Marketing Communication Development and Analysis
CRS_DESC: Analysis and development of online communication and marketing campaigns; exploration of current Internet best practices in social media, SEM, privacy, location-based marketing, and online measurement.

Communication strategies in a global marketing environment; analysis of global â€“ local challenges and opportunities; effective global integrated communication to create and sustain competitive advantage
Global influences on linear and streaming television and theatrical. Case analyses of organizations and content focusing on interconnected partnerships and promotions to attract local audiences.
Specialized writing for persuasive and strategic communication contexts. Intensive focus on public relations writing for print, online, broadcast, and social media.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PR department but may qualify for major credit in CMGT. To register, enroll in PR 562.

CRS_NAME: Methodological Fundamentals of Big Data in Communication
CRS_DESC: Understanding of fundamental methodological issues about big data: types, platforms, tools, analysis techniques, and relevant theoretical frameworks.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Applied Communication Research, Communication Data Science, Communication Data Science, Communication Management, Specialized Journalism
  • Note: Section 21781 is for Communication Management students only. Please be mindful when requesting d-clearances to register.

CRS_DESC: Students master skills and strategies to distinguish the truly influential from the merely popular, manage international influencer campaigns and develop successful influencers.
How to use effective organizational communication to facilitate crisis prevention, provide leadership during a crisis and manage organizational change.
Theoretical foundations of social marketing and entertainment education; uses of dramatic serials, telenovelas and animation to promote human rights; program design, evaluation.
Examination of social scientific theory and research on patterns of media content; effects of mass media exposure on individuals and society; and industry practices.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication Management

CRS_DESC: Conceptualization of client research problems: sampling and segmentation; advanced questionnaire design; audience observation; quantitative-qualitative analyses and synthesis; effective communication of findings and solutions.

How to communicate through storytelling in contemporary culture. Strategic story development for brands, for self-branding, and for social impact. Story creation utilizes narrative theories and workshop-style participatory activities.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the school. Graded CR/NC.
Field experience in applying communication principles to settings in organizations, campaigns, or other contexts; analysis and assessment of issues and problems.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Global Communication, Communication Management, Communication, Digital Social Media, Public Diplomacy (Practitioner and Mid-Career Professional),, Public Diplomacy
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student
  • Note: Section 21822 is with Prof. Ben Lee.

CRS_DESC: Communication management research project design and execution - thesis formulation, literature review, methods choice and instrument design. Analysis and reporting with appropriate quantitative or qualitative techniques.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CMGT 501 and CMGT 540
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication Management

CRS_DESC: Communication management research project design and execution - thesis formulation, literature review, methods choice and instrument design. Analysis and reporting with appropriate quantitative or qualitative techniques.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CMGT 597A
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication Management

CRS_DESC: Social scientific inquiry into human communication; core theories of message production and reception in interpersonal, group and organizational contexts.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Principles and practices of effective oral communication; analysis of the speaking-listening process; selection and organization of speech materials; use of new presentation technologies.

Students address communication issues in a field setting. They will evaluate communication practices using appropriate methodology. Projects are jointly evaluated by internship supervisor and professor. Sophomore standing. Graded: CR/NC. Not for major credit for Communication majors.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration closed to the following class level(s): Freshmen

CRS_DESC: Examines cultural institutions, ideologies, artifacts, and productions; role of culture in everyday life; cultural studies as methodology; culture and power.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Economic and political economic principles for the analysis of communication and media industries including broadcasting, newspapers, motion pictures, music, video games, advertising and public relations.

Theoretical foundation for understanding the construction, consumption, and consequences of entertainment from classical to contemporary times; situates entertainment within the ecology of information and communication.
Experimental and survey methods for communication study; basic statistical concepts, procedures, and tests.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Theories and research in social influence; strategies and tactics of persuasive communications in such settings as politics, public relations, advertising, business.
Students learn to be consumers rather than creators of social science research. Examines the challenges and opportunities of communicating research through mass media.
Music as inter-cultural communication and method for exploring race and ethnicity in the constitution of American culture and American self; role of music industry.
Nature and functions of communication in human conflict; development of communication skills for managing conflict productively in interpersonal, organizational and intercultural contexts.

Cultural, social, political, and economic dynamics of communication technologies, including internet architecture, social media, participatory cultures, privacy, surveillance, networked journalism, big data, algorithms, online activism.
Interplay between media and society, including family and children's socialization, inter-group relations and community, pornography and violence, gender and race, media ethics, conduct of politics.
Forms of civic life; opportunities and obstacles in forming, participating in, and disrupting community; issues of knowledge, power, identity; theories/methods of rhetorical analysis and production.
Survey of mass communication research; history, content, effects, theories, and policy implications of various media.

Group process theories relevant to communicative behavior in small group/team settings, including information exchange, decision making, leadership, and meetings; student team projects testing theoretic propositions.
Social media within the broader social, political, and historical contexts; key themes include labor, Web 2.0, self-branding, celebrity, participation, privacy, online shaming, and activism.

Basic argumentation theory including analysis. Research and evidence, case construction, refutation; discursive and visual argument; diverse fields of advocacy including law, politics, organizations, interpersonal relations.

Cultural variables and social psychological processes that influence intercultural interaction; relationship between communication and culture in diverse settings including business, medicine, and education.
CRS_NOTE: • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_NAME: The LGBTQ Revolution and the Media
CRS_DESC: Explores the role of the media in the LGBTQ revolution that transformed the lives of sexual and gender minorities in the United States.
This course examines philosophies and popular representations of technology from the origins of western culture to the present and identifies the complex attitudes toward technology.

Cultural implications of computer-mediated communication and related media. Ideological responses to media innovation; debates over artificial intelligence, virtual communities, and virtual reality. Recommended preparation: COMM 339.

CRS_NAME: Social and Economic Implications of Communication Technologies
CRS_DESC: Social and economic impacts of information and communication technologies; social factors that shape technological change; issues include access, privacy, freedom of expression, productivity, democratic control.
Advertising as a mode of communication; US advertising history and institutions; economic and policy contexts (domestic and global); critical analysis of advertising texts
Representations of Los Angeles communicated in diverse media; the city as a rhetorical text; analysis of cultural identities, art, architecture and representations in popular culture.
Theoretical approaches to the study of media consumption and audiences; examines international media and consumption practices; explores new media's impact on consumption.
Examination of the modern city as a communicative text with London as the case study.
Students explore the theoretical and practical issues involved in designing effective media and communication projects for social change.
Introduces public diplomacy as a central feature of contemporary international relations and challenges students to locate themselves as both its target and practitioners.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PUBD department but may qualify for major credit in COMM. To register, enroll in PUBD 369.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of how freedom of speech has been adapted and applied to "new media" from film to computer algorithms and video games.

Oral and written communication skills demanded in the workplace including informative and persuasive speeches; interviewing; team communication; and training material preparation. Recommended preparation: COMM 204
Directed individual research studies of contemporary problems. Supervised laboratory experience. Open only to members of the University debate squad.
Explores social, political and ethical issues in elite sports and how issues are addressed through popular media; examination includes the relationship between sports and politics.

CRS_NAME: Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
CRS_DESC: An inside look at the important stories, topical issues, trends and historical developments related to the growing influence of business and media on college and professional sports; identifying the key components and meeting the influencers in class that help shape the business side of sports, while recognizing the role the media plays in providing daily coverage across multiple platforms.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the JOUR department but may qualify for major credit in COMM. To register, enroll in JOUR 380.

CRS_DESC: Rhetorical and critical approaches to sports and public discourse; application to sports organizations, the news and popular media; representations of gender and race in sports.

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Dance

CRS_DESC: Viewing and investigating thematically organized Iconic Dance Films, analyzing different director's and choreographer's cinematic and choreographic strategies. Viewing and discussing a different film each week.
Creative choreography of theatrical dance for the screen. Emphasis on rhythmic analysis, versatility, composition, notation techniques, and stylizing.

African Dance technique at the beginning/intermediate level: knowing, understanding, experiencing culture, emphasizing cultural traditions, community outreach and diversity; works through artistic process, practice, performance, and related activities, using dance, theatre and music work rooted in the African tradition and contemporary African aesthetics; focus on West and Central African traditional dance and music.

An introduction to methods developed from modern and post-modern dance techniques, including the study of the rebellious, individualistic, and democratic nature of dance in the 20th and 21st centuries.

Continued study in the fusion of modern, post-modern dance and classical ballet techniques encompassing the study of the democratic nature of dance and choreographic composition in the 20th and 21st centuries.

An introduction to Classical Ballet technique with beginning-level barre and center work, focusing on correct body alignment and musicality. Development of a basic knowledge of ballet history and terminology.

Continued study of Classical Ballet technique with intermediate-level barre and center work, focusing on developing greater clarity, coordination, musicality, and knowledge of ballet history and terminology.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 183A
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 183A, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: Intermediate/advanced study of Classical Ballet technique with emphasis on clarity, precision, musicality, movement quality, and artistic expression. Introduction of beats, tours, advanced adagio and allegro combinations, and optional pointe work.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 183B
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 183A/B, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: Advanced/pre-professional study of Classical Ballet, continuing and deepening emphasis on clarity, precision, musicality, movement quality, and artistic expression. Further development of beats, tours, advanced adagio and allegro combinations, and optional pointe work.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 183C
  • Note: If you have significant dance experience, have not taken DANC 183A/B/C, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: An introduction to Jazz Dance technique, focusing on African and Latin based diaspora dances with European influences, improvisation, and strength/stretching series.

CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 184B
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 184A/B, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: An introduction to elements of Hip Hop Dance, including technique, movement, musical rhythm, tempo, and phrasing, as well as the historical context required to develop the skills needed to practice and perform this popular dance form.

CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 185A
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 185A, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

Inspired by the high energy music from Indian films, Bollywood is a fusion form that combines traditional Indian folk and classical dances with Hip Hop, Jazz, Latin, and Middle-eastern dance.

Introduction to International Standard, International Latin, and American Style ballroom dances. Designed to introduce students to the fundamentals of ballroom dance, emphasizing partner connection, communication, and creativity, with the practical application of dance within a social setting.

Continued study in International Standard, International Latin, and American Style ballroom dances. Designed for advanced knowledge in ballroom styles, emphasizing rhythmic sequences, partnering techniques, complex patterns, and performance quality.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 188A
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 188A, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: Analysis of forces acting on particles and rigid bodies in static equilibrium; equivalent systems of forces; friction; centroids and moments of inertia; introduction to energy methods.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (MATH 125 or MATH 126 or MATH 129 or MATH 226 or MATH 229)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 125 or MATH 126 or MATH 129 or MATH 226 or MATH 229)

CRS_DESC: Stress, strain and deflection of mechanical elements due to tension, shear, bending, or torsion; combined loads; plates, shells, statically indeterminate structures; strength-based design, trusses.
Common tools for Aerospace and Mechanical engineers: vectors, matrices, fundamentals of python, data manipulation and analysis, statistics, data presentation, optimization, large data sets.
Performance of flight vehicles; maximum speed, rate-of-climb, range, and endurance; basic stability and control, weight, and balance; computer exercises.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended for entry in local and national design competitions. Intended for lower division students or those with little prior project experience. Graded CR/NC.
Reference frames and coordinate systems; relationships between forces, moments, power, linear/angular momentum, and energy for particles and rigid bodies; particle and rigid body systems.
Modeling of lumped parameter elements and systems; free and forced response of first and second order systems; design oriented approach to dynamic systems.
Introduction to the finite element method; practical application of computer analysis tools for structural analysis and design.
Fluid statics; conservation of mass, momentum, and energy in integral and differential form; applications. Laminar and turbulent pipe flow; compressible flow; potential flow over bodies.
Fundamental laws of thermodynamics applied to actual and perfect gases and vapors; energy concepts, processes and applications; energy, entropy and exergy analysis; power and refrigeration systems.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: PHYS 151 and (MATH 125 or MATH 126 or MATH 129 or MATH 226 or MATH 229)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: PHYS 151 and 1 from (MATH 125 or MATH 126 or MATH 129 or MATH 226 or MATH 229)

CRS_DESC: Coordinated laboratory and lecture sequence on aeromechanical instrumentation, test and measurement, integration of mechanical, optical and electronic components and technical communication.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: AME 341A
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Theories of failure, shear center, unsymmetrical bending, curved beams, torsion of non-circular sections; cylinders, rotating discs, thermal stresses, inelastic strains, energy methods.

Introduction to computational methods in engineering: learning to develop and implement numerical algorithms for solving a range of mathematics, physics, and engineering problems. Suitable for undergraduate students in aerospace, bio, civil and mechanical engineering.

Design of mechanical systems using advanced graphics techniques; computer-aided drafting, design optimization, elements of computer graphics, solids modeling; introduction to computer-aided manufacturing. Prerequisite: AME 204 or CE 225. Recommended preparation: AME 308.
Modelling, analysis, integration, layout and performance analysis of a mechanical system to meet the specified design requirements.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior

CRS_DESC: Physics of turbine operation; design and analysis for the development of turbine hardware for propulsion and power generation. Recommended preparation: Familiarity with Matlab.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

CRS_NAME: Mechanics and Transport in Medicine and Biology
CRS_DESC: Introduction to mechanics of living organs; analysis of fluid and solid forces acting on biological systems; introductory hemodynamics and bio-transport phenomena.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Recommended Preparation: Fundamental Physics, Statics, and Differential Equations

CRS_DESC: Theory of free and forced vibrations with and without damping; systems of single and multiple degrees of freedom; iteration; methods; vibration isolation; instrumentation.
General principles underlying heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation; steady and transient conditions; heat exchangers.

Analysis of combustion engines: reciprocating-piston, gas turbines, rockets. Tradeoffs compared to non-combustion sources. Ideal and non-ideal cycle analysis and performance evaluation; pollutant formation and remediation.
Team engineering design project to model, construct and test a physical principle or system. Complete industrial research project including proposal, design review, presentation, technical report.
Individual engineering projects designed and constructed to modeland test a physical principle or system.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: AME 441a
  • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_DESC: Vibration measurement and analysis; simulation, design, and experimental verification of mechanical control systems; system identification; implementation of controllers; performance evaluation via experimentation and stimulation.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (AME 420 or AME 451 or EE 482)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Transform methods, block diagrams; transfer functions; stability; root-locus and frequency domain analysis and design; application to flight control, state space and multiloop systems.
Introduction to micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS); scaling effects; materials and structures in MEMS; MEMS sensing and actuation principles; microfabrication.
Basic relations describing the inviscid flow field about bodies and wings moving at subsonic and supersonic speeds.

CRS_NAME: Modeling and Simulation of Subsurface Flow Systems
CRS_DESC: Properties of reservoir fluids, volumetric and material balances for gas and oil reservoirs; reservoir modeling concepts.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: PTE 463
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PTE department but may qualify for major credit in AME. To register, enroll in PTE 464.
  • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_DESC: Aircraft design and analysis, design requirements and specifications; integration of structure, propulsion, control system, and aerodynamic configuration; performance analysis and prediction.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_NAME: Mechanics of Composite Materials for Modern Structures
CRS_DESC: Current and potential applications of composite materials including manufacturing methods; determining mechanical properties; failure analysis; and design, inspection, and repair considerations.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: AME 204
  • Note: . Current and potential applications of composite materials including manufacturing methods; determining mechanical properties; failure analysis; and design, inspection, and repair considerations.

CRS_DESC: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended for entry in local and national design competitions. Intended for students with prior project experience. Upper division standing. Graded CR/NC.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_NAME: Innovative Conceptual Design for New Product Development
CRS_DESC: A logic-based framework for conceptual design, including systematic concept generation and improvement, in innovative product developments.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the ISE department but may qualify for major credit in AME. To register, enroll in ISE 501.

CRS_DESC: Specific problems and methods of analysis in mechanical systems design.
Use of mechanical, electrical and computer engineering, math and computer science to design of high performance and sophisticated products and processes and systems involving mechatronics.

Compressible flow equations; Rayleigh/Fanno flows; shock/expansion waves and interactions; potential flow, small disturbance theory and similarity; hypersonics; viscosity, high-temperature and radiation effects.

Advanced topics in combustion including analytical methods, stretch effects, stability, ignition and extinction of flames, plasma-assisted combustion, turbulence effects, detonations, and micropower generation.

CRS_NAME: Thermal and Biological Transport Phenomena II
CRS_DESC: Analytical techniques for solving convective heat and mass transfer problems; applications include heat/mass transfer in biological systems as well as traditional industrial settings.

CRS_NAME: Nonlinear Dynamical Systems, Vibrations, and Chaos
CRS_DESC: Flows on a line and circle; phase plane methods; bifurcation theory; limit cycle/relaxation oscillations; chaotic systems, one-dimensional maps, the Lorenz equations, fractals and strange attractors.

CRS_NAME: Partial Differential Equations for Engineering Applications
CRS_DESC: Solving linear heat, wave, Laplace and Poisson equations, separation of variables and Fourier series, special functions, Fourier and Laplace transforms, characteristics, Greens functions, similarity solutions.
Stress Analysis. Linear Elasticity. Thin Plates. Finite Element Methods. Structural stability. Vibration of Continuous Systems. Emphasis on aerospace and aeronautical applications

Generalized curvilinear coordinates; grid generation; numerical techniques for transonic and supersonic inviscid flows: boundary layer flows; reduced Navier-Stokes equations; compressible and incompressible viscous flows. Recommended preparation: AME 511 or AME 530a.

Computer control as applied to machine tools, mechanical manipulators, and other mechanical machinery; discrete time controller design; microprocessor implementation of motion and force control servos.
Overview of methods and tools for creating products that are easier to manufacture and assemble thereby reducing manufacturing costs.
Introduction to systems architecture in aerospace, electrical, computer, and manufacturing systems emphasizing the conceptual and acceptance phases and using heuristics.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the SAE department but may qualify for major credit in AME. To register, enroll in SAE 549.

CRS_NAME: Seminar in Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering
CRS_DESC: Recent developments and research in aerospace and mechanical engineering and related fields. Oral and written reports.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

CRS_DESC: Phase plane, describing function, applications to mechanical and aerospace systems. Lyapunov stability theory. Popov theorem. Circle criterion. Lyapunov redesign. Sliding mode control. Backstepping. Passivity.

Design, analysis and implementation of digital control systems using microcomputers; Z-transform methods; frequency domain and state space approach, system identification; computational aspects; sampling and quantization.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: EE 482
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the EE department but may qualify for major credit in AME. To register, enroll in EE 543.

CRS_DESC: Overview and working principles of commonly used additive manufacturing processes; process models; process and material selection; cost estimation methods; current applications and future directions.
Behavior of materials under cyclic and static fatigue; plastic instability; life-time predictions; brittle and ductile fracture; crack propagation and plastic blunting.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the MASC department but may qualify for major credit in AME. To register, enroll in MASC 560.

CRS_NAME: Design and Advanced Manufacturing of Machine Components
CRS_DESC: Modern CAE design for automotive and aerospace machine components; characterization methods, design tools and manufacturing techniques. Intended for students with prior CAE experience.

CRS_NAME: Survey of Energy and Power for a Sustainable Future
CRS_DESC: Power production includes conventional fossil fuels, synthetic fuels, hydroelectric, solar, wind, geothermal, biomass and nuclear. The environmental consequences of various energy sources are discussed.

Analysis of repairs in aircraft/launch vehicles. Flexible dynamics for spacecraft, random vibration, deployable spacecraft components, certification of thermal protection systems. Practical finite element analysis.
Materials selection in relationship to design and fabrication, economic considerations, methodology of selection, performance parameters; case studies.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the MASC department but may qualify for major credit in AME. To register, enroll in MASC 583.

CRS_DESC: Coordinate systems and transformations. Spherical trigonometry. Filtering and estimation. Spacecraft orbits and orbital maneuvers. Rocket propulsion, spacecraft attitude dynamics, spacecraft communications, and space environment.
Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects. Intended for lower-division students or those with little prior project experience. Departmental approval.
Introduction to compressible and rarefied gas flows with applications to rocket propulsion and the dynamics of supersonic and hypersonic vehicles and spacecraft; ionized gases and plasmas.
Introduction to spacecraft systems: propulsion, attitude dynamics and control, structures, communications, power, thermal control. Space environment. Systems engineering as applied to spacecraft.
Space systems engineering process: requirements definition; trade studies; system integration; technical reviews; cost and schedule development; case studies; ethics. Capstone design experience.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ASTE 331 or ASTE 331A)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior

CRS_DESC: Two-body motion. Rigid-body motion. Attitude dynamics and maneuvers. Spacecraft stabilization: gravity gradient, reaction wheels, magnetic torques. Thruster attitude control. Senior standing.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior

CRS_DESC: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

Course content to be selected each semester from current developments in astronautics, space technology, and related fields.

CRS_NAME: Design of Low Cost Space Missions
CRS_DESC: Reviews all aspects of space mission design for practical approaches to reducing cost. Examines "LightSat" mission experience and potential applicability to large scale missions. Graduate standing in engineering or science. Recommended preparation: ASTE 520 or some experience in space engineering.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student, Doctoral Student

CRS_NAME: Space Exploration Architectures Concept Synthesis Studio
CRS_DESC: Programmatic/conceptual design synthesis/choice creation methods for complex space missions. Aerospace system engineering/architecting tools to create innovative projects. Evaluated by faculty/industry/NASA experts. Graduate standing in engineering or science. Recommended preparation: ASTE-520 or experience in space industry
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student, Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Space environments and interactions with space systems. Vacuum, neutral and ionized species, plasma, radiation, micrometeoroids. Phenomena important for spacecraft operations.
Engineering fundamentals of spacecraft systems design and analysis to support human life in the space environment.

Liquid-propelled rocket propulsion systems. Capillary devices for gas-free liquid acquisition in zero gravity. Ground and in-orbit operations. Propellant life predictions and spacecraft end-of-life de-orbiting strategies.

Nuclear, electric, sails, and far-term propulsion systems. Overviews of nozzles, heat transfer, electromagnetics, rarefied gases, and plasma physics. Analysis of electrothermal, electrostatic and electromagnetic thrusters. Graduate standing in engineering or science.
Fundamentals, technologies, and design of space launch vehicles. Propulsion, trajectory analysis and optimization, static and dynamic structural loads, stability, control, and safety.

Space missions, rocket dynamics, and propulsion requirements. Thermodynamics and combustion; compressible gas dynamics in nozzles. Liquid- and solid-propellant rockets; launch systems. Advanced propulsion.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: Physical principles; two-body and central force motion; trajectory correction maneuvers; position and velocity in conic orbits; Lambert's problem; celestial mechanics; orbital perturbations.

Introduction to solar arrays, batteries, nuclear power sources, mechanical energy storage. Application, theory of operation, practical considerations. Subsystem topologies and performance. Design optimization techniques. Graduate standing in engineering or science.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student, Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Dynamics of systems of particles and rigid bodies; spacecraft attitude systems; attitude maneuvers (spin, precession, nutation, etc.); attitude stabilization and attitude determination; simulation methods.

Historical development and survey of major areas comprising biomedical engineering: theoretical neurobiology and systems physiology, biomedical instrumentation, artificial organ and prosthetic devices, biomedical computer applications.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for one lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Examination of the technical and practical challenges involved in the development of medical devices, including neural implants, in industry and the clinical setting. Recommended preparation: BME 101.

Computational methods for simulation of circulatory, respiratory, pharmacokinetic, and neural models. Quadrature, differential equations, systems of linear equations, simulation languages, experimental statistics.
CRS_NOTE:
• Corequisite: MATH 245
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Concepts of computer-aided design in 2-dimensions and 3-dimensions. Creating advanced parts using extrusions, surfaces, and equation driven sketches. Forming assemblies, and sub-assemblies, for motion analysis
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the ITP department but may qualify for major credit in BME. To register, enroll in ITP 308.

CRS_DESC: A thorough bioengineering treatment of the physiological properties of various mammalian organ systems: e.g., cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and musculoskeletal.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: BISC 220 and MATH 245
  • Corequisite: EE 202
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Application of instrumentation and measurement techniques to biomedical engineering projects involving measurement, replacement or augmentation of biomedical systems.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: BME 210
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Introduction to technologies used for rehabilitation and improved function, including limb and spinal orthoses and prostheses, gait analysis and sensory aids and augmentation.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Biomaterials and Tissue Engineering
CRS_DESC: Study of stem cells, biomaterials, and microfabrication techniques used to engineer human tissues. Labs for muscle tissue engineering, microscopy, and fabrication of cell culture substrates.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CHEM 322A and BISC 220
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one lab

CRS_NAME: Fundamentals of Craniofacial and Dental Technology
CRS_DESC: Biomedical engineering and technology applied to oral health professions. Dental biomaterials, CAD-CAM, digital dental technology and tissue engineering applications to craniofacial diseases, disorders, and enhancements. Recommended preparation: junior standing.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the DENT department but may qualify for major credit in BME. To register, enroll in DENT 412.

CRS_DESC: Non-ionizing radiation imaging techniques; MRI, ultrasound and emerging optical imaging techniques including fluorescence, Raman and photoacoustic imaging; engineering and modern physics concepts; clinical applications.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Biosensors and Diagnostics Devices
CRS_DESC: Introduction to biosensor technology, including classification and bio-recognition elements, and the integration of engineering and biology for the design of point-of-care biosensors.
Continued development of the Senior Design project; identify possible improvements and establish new requirements; design, build and demonstrate an improved prototype.
Theoretical, quantitative, and experimental methods for understanding and engineering cellular systems for biotechnological applications.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CHE 330 and BISC 320
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the CHE department but may qualify for major credit in BME. To register, enroll in CHE 489.

CRS_DESC: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Current trends and developments in the field of biomedical engineering.
Advanced topics in selected biomedical systems: cardiopulmonary, neuromuscular, renal and endocrine. Duplicates credit in BME 503ab.
Integration of biomedical science, engineering principles and state-of-the-art technology for the study of selected physiological systems in the laboratory setting. Laboratory.

CRS_NAME: Bioengineering of Disease and Cell Therapeutics
CRS_DESC: Introduction to micro-/nano-technologies, microscopy, single-cell techniques, materials, surface chemistry, pathology, cancer, immunology, cell therapy and grant writing in biomedical research.

Classification; representation; statistical analysis; orthogonal expansions; least-squares estimation; harmonic analysis; Fourier, Laplace and Z transforms; the linear system; filtering; modeling and simulation; linear control theory.
Application of linear time- and frequency-domain techniques, adaptive filtering, nonlinear dynamics and machine learning approaches to the analysis of physiological signals.

Presentation and application of advanced computational/mathematical methodologies for analysis of biomedical time-series data, emphasizing predictive analytics to advance biomedical science and improve clinical support systems.
Advanced scientific and engineering principles of biomedical imaging including magnetic resonance, X-ray computed tomography, ultrasound and single photon and positron emission tomography.

CRS_NAME: Medical Diagnostics, Therapeutics and Informatics Applications
CRS_DESC: Picture archive communication system (PACS) design and implementation; clinical PACS-based imaging informatics; telemedicine/teleradiology; image content indexing, image data mining; grid computing in large-scale imaging informatics; image-assisted diagnosis, surgery and therapy.

Computational methods for simulation and analysis of metabolic networks, cellular signaling pathways, and gene regulatory networks. Biochemical kinetics, differential equations, stability analysis, sensitivity analysis.
Graded CR/NC.

Principles and biomedical applications of micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) and nanotechnology, including microfluidics, nanowire sensors, nanomotors, quantum dots, biofuel cells and molecular imaging.

Advanced studies of the basic neuroscience, engineering design requirements and technological issues associated with implantable neural prostheses, with paticular emphasis on retinal and cortical function.
Conception and design of health-related, technological products; regulated aspects of medical products; risk analysis and design controls; engineering tools commonly used in product development.

• Prerequisite: BME 650
  • Corequisite: ISE 501
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

CRS_DESC: Study of stem cells, biomaterials, and microfabrication techniques used to engineer human tissues. Labs for muscle tissue engineering, microscopy, and fabrication of cell culture substrates.

  • Corequisite: CHE 330 and CHE 350

CRS_NAME: Heat and Mass Transfer in Chemical Engineering Processes
CRS_DESC: Differential and macroscopic equations of heat transfer; molecular and continuum approaches to diffusion and convection in fluids; simultaneous heat, mass and momentum transfer.
Environmental impact and energy use in the production of natural materials, synthetic materials, biodegradable materials, and composites made of natural and synthetic materials
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (CHEM 105A or CHEM 115A or MASC 110) and (MATH 225 or MATH 235 or MATH 245)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (CHEM 105A or CHEM 115A or MASC 110) and 1 from (MATH 225 or MATH 235 or MATH 245)

CRS_NAME: Modeling and Simulation of Subsurface Flow Systems
CRS_DESC: Properties of reservoir fluids, volumetric and material balances for gas and oil reservoirs; reservoir modeling concepts.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: PTE 463
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PTE department but may qualify for major credit in CHE. To register, enroll in PTE 464.
  • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_DESC: Design and evaluate a chemical process/plant based on safety, economics, sustainability and engineering viability through the application of unit operations, thermodynamics, kinetics and separations.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CHE 485
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior

CRS_DESC: Theoretical, quantitative, and experimental methods for understanding and engineering cellular systems for biotechnological applications.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in chemical engineering and related fields.
Understanding deep learning: for students in engineering, physical and life sciences and computer science with mathematical background.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the MASC department but may qualify for major credit in CHE. To register, enroll in MASC 520.

CRS_DESC: Elements of classical and statistical thermodynamics. Molecular theory and property estimation, emphasis on multi-component multi-phase fluid systems. Advanced applications, including highly non-ideal solutions, polymers, electrolytes.
Seminars to cover recent developments in the field of chemical engineering given by invited speakers.

CRS_NAME: Advanced Separations for Energy and Environmental Applicatio
CRS_DESC: Experimental techniques for separation and bioseparation processes and theoretical and computational techniques for modeling them. Energy and environmental applications.
Research leading to the Master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of chemical engineering.

Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: Graphic communication and drawing; Free-hand sketching; Use of CAD software; Drawing in 2-D, including lettering, dimensioning, and detailing; Drawing and modeling in 3-D.

CRS_NAME: Programming for Civil and Environmental Engineers
CRS_DESC: Computer programming, organization of problems for computational solution, flow charts, programming; numerical methods; analysis and solution of civil engineering problems.
Analysis of stress and strain; axial, flexural, and torsional behavior of slender bars; elastic deflections; combined stresses; introduction to elastic stability and energy methods.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CE 215
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Fluid statics; relative velocity field; total acceleration; divergence theorem; conservation of mass, energy, and momentum applied to engineering problems in laminar and turbulent flow.
Application of computer-oriented numerical analysis methods and tools to a broad spectrum of practical science and engineering problems. Use of Python, R and computer algebra.
Physiochemical characterization of water, soil and air; chemical processes in aquatic, atmospheric, and geospheric environments; air, soil and water pollution chemistry and abatement.

Legal aspects of property development and construction: land use, construction practices and specifications, architecture and engineering contracts, agency, subcontracting, professional registration, liability, insurance, liens, bonds.

Control and utilization of inland and coastal water, quantitative hydrology, groundwater, probability concepts, extreme events, coastal hydrodynamics, wave-structures interactions, multiple purposes water projects, economic study.
Design of structural systems in wood, steel, concrete and masonry, and the performance of structural systems for wind and seismic forces.
Analyze continuous beams, trusses and frame structures using analytical methods and Matlab programming; finite element analysis of plane stress problems, steel beams and concrete beam-column joints.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CE 358
  • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the construction processes; estimating and bidding, construction administration, planning and scheduling, equipment and methods, labor relations, cost control systems, safety and ethics.
Fundamental principles and practices of advanced building cost estimating using Revit Models and industry standard databases.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Junior, Master Student, Senior

CRS_DESC: Current procedures in selected fields of construction; organization and planning; equipment economics; machinery.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Junior, Master Student, Senior

CRS_NAME: Water Supply and Sewerage System Design
CRS_DESC: Design of water supply systems, storm drains, sanitary sewers, and lift stations.

Fundamentals of geotechnical engineering; soil classification, seepage, stress-strain behavior, shear strength, consolidation, design of retaining structures and foundations, and slope stability. Soil testing. Duplicates credit in CE 464 and CE 468.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CE 225
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_NAME: Civil and Environmental Engineering Capstone Design
CRS_DESC: Civil and Environmental Engineering capstone design project incorporating all disciplines of Civil Engineering and Environmental Engineering.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: CE 408 and (CE 456 or CE 457 or CE 476 or CE 485)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CE 408 and 1 from (CE 456 or CE 457 or CE 476 or CE 485)
  • Note: Section designated for ENE students. Students should meet in same location as CE 480, section 29677.

CRS_DESC: Principles of engineering economics; modeling and evaluation of receipts and outlays timing; relevance to and applications within Civil and Environmental Engineering projects.

CRS_NAME: Innovation in Engineering and Design for Global Crises
CRS_DESC: Engineering innovation to design products, services and technologies with a human-centered approach to help solve the needs of people affected by global crises.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in civil engineering and related fields.

Systems, processes, and constraints governing the initiation, direction, engineering, and delivery of major construction projects. Professional construction management, responsibilities, and practice.
Fundamental accounting principles, financial analysis and financial control, strategic management and a review of alternative project delivery methods.

CRS_NAME: Data Management for Civil and Environmental Engineering
CRS_DESC: The basics of databases and database management systems as applied to engineering problems. Introduction to data mining concepts, techniques and knowledge discovery in database principles.
Software and digital tools for traffic analysis, highway and railway design, transportation demand analysis and public transportation planning.
Engineering problems discussed on a physical basis with solutions via mathematical tools: Fourier series; Fourier and Laplace transforms; partial differential equations, wave and Laplace equations.
Application of Fourier series, wavelets, auto-regressive models and Markov models to civil engineering systems. Introduction to deep learning methods and applications to time series analysis.
Fundamental and design-oriented understanding of the "state-of-the-practice" of geotechnical earthquake engineering, related to analysis and design of foundations, slopes and retaining walls.

Transforming transportation with technological advancements; implementing smart mobility solutions to enhance transportation efficiency, sustainability and equity; measuring network performance with regional mobility indicators.
Advanced beam flexural analysis; shear behavior of beams; beam-columns and interaction diagrams; torsion; structural wall design; analysis of D-regions; nonlinear behavior of RC systems.
Introduction to the concept, principles and applications of prestressed concrete; covers the analysis and design of prestressed concrete structures.

Forced vibrations of discrete and distributed systems; energy methods; analytical dynamics; computational techniques; approximate methods; random vibration concepts; nonstationary response; structural control; nonlinear system response.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: Develop skills for using current knowledge about structural response in the design of earthquake resistant structures.

CRS_NAME: Fundamental Concepts of Computing and Programming in Civil and Environmental Engineering
CRS_DESC: Concepts of computing and programming related to engineering; Form and operation of modern computational devices; Data structures and algorithms that support CEE software applications.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Civil Engineering, Civil Engineering (Transportation Engineering), Civil Engineering (Transportation Systems), Civil Engineering (Water and Waste Management), Construction Management, Civil Engineering (Construction Engineering), Environmental Engineering, Civil Engineering (Structural Engineering), Civil Engineering (Advanced Design and Construction,Technology)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: Project controls principles including costs and schedules, cost engineering concepts, schedule development, status evaluation, progress monitoring and responses to variances and changes.
This project-oriented course elaborates on the process of engaging creative thought, tools and techniques for invention, and issues involved in bringing inventions to the production phase.
Integration of architecture, engineering and construction practices through the development of a construction project.
Planning, design, staging, construction, test and maintenance of the public works and facilities for land, water, and air transportation.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of civil engineering.

CRS_NAME: Methods and Modeling Tools for Transportation Planning
CRS_DESC: Background applications of established urban travel forecasting procedures; land use; trip-generation, trip-distribution, modal-choice, trip-assignment; evaluation; criticisms.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PPD department but may qualify for major credit in CE. To register, enroll in PPD 633.

CRS_DESC: Fundamentals of urban mass transit planning. Topics include the fiscal context of mass transit planning, fares and farebox recovery, ridership forecasts, land development near transit, and transit operations, scheduling, and network design.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PPDE department but may qualify for major credit in CE. To register, enroll in PPDE 637.

CRS_DESC: Research leading to the Doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
